Evaluation of preliminary data analysis framework in software cost estimation based on ISBSG R9 Data
bibo:abstract: Previous research has argued that preliminary data analysis is necessary for software cost estimation. In this paper, a framework for such analysis is applied to a substantial corpus of historical project data (ISBSG R9 data), selected without explicit bias. The consequent analysis yields sets of dominant variables, which are then used to construct project effort estimation models. Performance of the predictors on the raw variables and the extracted sets of variables is then measured in terms of Mean Magnitude of Relative Error (MMRE), Median of Magnitude of Relative Error (MdMRE) and prediction at levels 0.05, 0.1, and 0.25. The results from the comparative evaluation suggest that more accurate prediction models can be constructed for the selected prediction techniques. The framework processed predictor variables are statistically significant, at the 95% confidence level for both parametric techniques and one non-parametric technique. The results are also compared with the latest published results obtained by other research based on the same data set. The comparison indicates that, the models constructed using framework processed data are generally more accurate.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of an Open 50' trimaran.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this assignment, which is a final year B.Eng YPD design dissertation is to do the preliminary design of an Open 50’ Trimaran. Multihulls are the fastest boats on the earth and have fascinated people for years since the Polynesians first discover a way to carry sails without adding a weight underneath the hull. Racing trimarans first appear in the 70s ocean singlehanded races such as the OSTAR, the former Europe 1 Star, won in 1972 by Alain Colas and Manureva first built for Eric Tabarly and rather known as Pen Duick IV. In 1978, a big monohull, Vendredi 13 is beaten on the finish line by a yellow trimaran four times smaller and multihulls have dominated the ocean races ever since. Multihulls are also good around the buoys, even if it is often denied: in 1988, the America’s Cup is won by Dennis Conner and a small catamarn, Stars & Stripes. Since the beginning of the development of racing multihulls in the 70s, these boats have greatly evolved and improved in many ways. Their behaviour and the loads carried are better explained and predicted and the development of new materials, a field constantly evolving, has allowed to design faster, stronger, lighter and more reliable multihulls than ever. The best example is The Race, the round the world race who took place this year. There was a big unknown about the possibilty of such huge boats sailing around the world and especially in the Southern Ocean. But these boats have been fabulous and will give now a very precious feedback for further development. Meanwhile, racing classes have been set up and the most important one nowadays is the 60’ Open. Most of the projects in this class are french ones but more and more people abroad are interested in this class which offers so much fun. The racing program is split into two parts: ocean transatlantique races, singlehanded and two-men raced and Grand Prix which are regatta around the buoys fully crewed.
The Preliminary Design of an Open 50’ Trimaran
__________________________________________________________________________________________
Alexis de Guillebon, B.Eng YPD
7
The class is very mature now and boats are very reliable as it has been proved during the last Route du Rhum in 1998, during which there hasn’t been any material failure nor capsize (apart from Yvan Bourgnon just out of St Malo harbour). But the 60’ Open are getting more expensive as they are more and more hi-tech: the last ones to have been launched since last summer are built with carbon pre-pregs for the first time. The cost of 60’ Open is about 1.5 million pounds and there are very few people who can afford such boats. Moreover they need a full-time crew to maintain them and prepare (and repare) them between the races. They also need very skilled and professional sailors as they are very tricky to sail: they can capsize very easily and are very stressful especially singlehanded. That’s why there has been a great interest after the last Route du Rhum in 1998 in setting up a new multihull class, less expensive and demanding in terms of preparation, physical condition, less time consuming and giving as much fun as the Open 60’. It has been found that a 50’ multihull budget would be half of an Open 60’s. This is a great opportunity for those who can’t afford a 60’ or simply don’t want to be involved in full time sailing as do the pro sailors, with all the constraints it implies. Unfortunately, sponsors may not be interested in the launch of a new class nowadays, as no Open 50’ has been built yet. There have been many preliminary designs from multihulls designers like Van Peteghem – Lauriot Prevost, Sebastien Schmidt, Marc Lombard but none of them has yet ended up in reality. The aim of this dissertation is to do a preliminary design of an Open 50’ multihull as it would be asked by a potential skipper. It means that this dissertation gives basic data of a potential racing 50’ trimaran but a real project would need further studies in many fields: fluids to find the best shape, FEA for the structure, which would need a lot of time and money and are far beyond a student’s means.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 30ft sportive cruiser
bibo:abstract: To design a high performance cruiser with a sportive character, which should still be easy to handle with a restricted crew. As it is supposed that people would stay onboard, the accommodation should be of a high standard and provide a comfortable living space. The cockpit should offer a good and safe working area for the crew and special attention ought to be paid for an all around visibility for the helmsman. The yacht should be able to anchor at an as wide as possible range of places even when the draught is restricted, as this would increase the area of operation and thus the pleasure of use of the boat. It should be thought about different possibilities of transporting the boat over dry land for example by use of a trailer. Special attention should be paid on seaworthiness and stability as this has a general influence on the safety and the comfort of the crew.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a customs catamaran
bibo:abstract:
The task decided for this design dissertation was to design a vessel for use by a Customs Authority. After spending some time in Australia, it had become apparent that this
country had some unique problems regarding the control of its territorial waters. As a reasonably wealthy country in the Asia-Pacific region, it is frequently a destination for would be illegal immigrants, trying to cross the relatively short stretch of water between Indonesia or Papua New Guinea and the north coast of Australia. Seizures of more than 100 people on a single vessel are not uncommon.
As with most, if not all, developed countries, drug trafficking is a common problem.
Due to the island nature of Australia, all of the imported narcotics must enter either by air or sea. It is the responsibility of the customs vessel to intercept those delivered by private sea-going vessels. This is an often-favoured route for smugglers due to the large quantities
that can be moved at once. Large quantities of narcotics can be found on vessels using these methods.
One of the major concerns for the design of a vessel for this particular task and operational area is the size of the territory under consideration. Australia has 37,000km of
coastline, much of it uninhabited. The patrol zone for a customs craft must also extend to the edge of these  territorial waters, 200km offshore. The total area of the Australian Exclusive Economic Zone is some 9 million square kilometres of sea3. These basic statistics begin to outline the importance of range, endurance and seakeeping as driving factors for the vessels’ design.

bibo:shortTitle: Workhorse 82' - preliminary design of an 82ft multi-purpose work boat catamaran.
bibo:abstract:
This dissertation details the method and decisions involved in the preliminary design of the Workhorse 80 multi purpose workboat catamaran, capable of handling up to two
containerised equipment units to fulfil oil spill response, fire fighting, diving, survey, ship and harbour maintenance and general site support duties. This design offers an interesting alternative to existing vessels.

bibo:shortTitle: Pilot boat for the Solent.
bibo:abstract:
Going back in history it was found that traditionally pilot age around Britain was organized by entrepreneurial mariners ,offering their services. This little group soon
banded in brother hood of pilots ,each group carving out there area. This was the birth of pilot age. Although at first it was an independent group, the system was enriched
in the first Pilot age act in the last century. Through the turn of the century with advanced science and technology, so has the organization experienced rapid transformation performing to its highest capacity excelling in the duties, which are to be performed. There are at least three categories of pilots, which are as follows,
- Deep sea or coastal pilot : assist ships between ports and areas
- Outer or sea pilot : conduct ship from sea to port or vice versa
- Inner or river canal and dock pilot : handle vessels in estuaries, river and canals
It should be noted that there are variations to these categories according to the geographical location, economical and commercial environment.
The main task of a pilot boat is to transfer the pilot to the required vessel in good condition. So that he can proceed in his duties in an efficient manner.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a J Class yacht (Gateless Kingdom).
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this project was to produce a preliminary design of a J class yacht, which meets the requirements set out in 2.0.
This project is intended to cover;
⇒ Requirements of the yacht
⇒ Parametric Study
⇒ Parameters
⇒ Hull design
⇒ Structural design
⇒ Weight estimation
⇒ General arrangement
⇒ Rig design
⇒ Sail plan
⇒ Deck design
⇒ Stability
⇒ Velocity prediction (VPP)
On completion of the project the author hopes to have produced a viable preliminary design, which fulfils the stated requirements.

bibo:shortTitle: The reporting of Haute de la Garenne is an example of sensationalism in the press and resulted in an unnecessary form of moral panic
The link between the Premier League and Sky Television has transformed football in England into an entertainment business at the expense of the game's traditional roots and culture
The influence of news media on the future of British prostitution
A 15m assault and logistics landing craft.
bibo:abstract:
The current troop insertion craft of the British Army has changed little in design since it was first developed in the first half of the 20th century. Their design relies on over specifying the engines in order to overcome the massive hydrodynamic resistance presented by their primitive shape. With the advent and evolution of technologies like aerospace driven Aluminium alloy, Rigid inflatable monohulls and catamarans there is much that can be done to improve the design of these craft.
In this current economic and political climate it is important to make any such craft versatile and cost effective. It is also important to remember the unique demands that the armed forces place upon their assets, both in testing and finally when in service. Often equipment having to be over engineered in order to remain reliable and combat effective. Additionally reflecting current military policy the vessel should comply with the standards of a regulatory body.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 65 knot sports cruiser.
bibo:abstract: In recent years there has been a large increase in the market for vessels from 40-55 foot in the sports boat area with speeds of 60 knots plus. Due to the climate and relatively cheap fuel the main location of this market is in America; and Mediterranean Europe. In Europe the Italian designers have been producing fast sports boats with classic Italian styling. England also offers a limited choice with Sunseeker in the forefront. So the dissertation proposal is to offer an alternative for the British and European market and also some competition for export to the highly competitive American market. The styling will be a key factor in the presentation of this vessel, styles are changing from curvy forms to that of sharper lines (e.g. Stealth bomber), this will be a main influence on the design.

bibo:shortTitle: A high latitudes sailing research vessel.
bibo:abstract: A brief was written to come up with a multi-purpose sailing vessel to operate in high latitude areas. Roles would include use as a research vessel and as an adventure charter vessel. Safety was considered to be of paramount importance and to that end the vessel was designed to have a full range of positive stability. This result was reached with the use of a larger than usual superstructure. The vessel is rigged as a cutter-rigged ketch for ease of handling and mast redundancy. Range under power is large and engine size ensures good speed in all wind conditions.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a high performance daysailer.
bibo:abstract:
Responding to the latest developments in yacht design, an attempt is made to design a High Performance 50’ daysailer. The design was connected with a study into an alternative appendage set up featuring a canting keel, a rudder and a canard.
The final yacht designed for this was a 52’ high performance yacht that is designed to satisfy the requirements of aesthetics and easy handling. It was found that in this design the twin foil arrangement is superior to the conventional arrangement in most cases.

bibo:shortTitle: Design for a long range insertion craft for use by the special forces.
bibo:abstract: The Special Forces are used by many of the world’s countries as specially trained units for operations involving land and sea. The Special Boat Service (SBS) is one such unit that specialise in water born and coastal operations. Over the years the SBS has adapted, and now require a quicker and more covert means of reaching their insertion. The projects aim is to design a Long Range Insertion Craft (LRIC) to meet these requirements, safely and effectively. This will be done by conducting studies on existing craft used by the Special Forces and analysing the data to obtain the principal dimensions for the design. Transportation of the LRIC will also be examined and the physical dimension restrictions applied to the design. A comparison of the petrol engine, diesel engine and the CODAG system was conducted. From this study the CODAG system was selected for it’s high power–to-weight ratio. From extensive research into the CODAG system, there is no system of the required size currently available. Therefore further research and discussion to concerned companies for specialist production is advised. A comparison into the direct drive, surface piercing propeller drive and the waterjet system was performed. The waterjet was the preferred system, due to it’s shallow water capabilities and low audio signature emission. To analyse the design, mass estimation calculations were conducted and a stability curve produced. The Lightship mass obtained from the mass estimation was 6.5 tonnes and the maximum GZ of the LRIC is 0.69 metres at 65.7 degrees. The design is quick and covert, and meets all criteria, but one. It is exceptional for swift undetected insertion into marine and coastal environments. The design, however, has one flaw in that the LRIC is too large in height to fit within the cabin of an HC-130J cabin.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into the manufacturing techniques of the sports car industry and their possible implications in the power craft industry.
bibo:abstract: When looking at the small craft industry especially at small motor boats and compare them to cars, the set up is quite similar if not simpler in the boat building industry. But looking at the turn over of the factories it is quite obvious that the car industry has a much grater capacity to produce. One of the main reasons for this is that a car is counted as a necessity wiliest a boat is thought as a luxury. This means that the demand for car will always be more than that for a boat but there is still a massive demand for pleasure craft. The way that most boats are manufactured is quite predated when you compare it to the way in witch cars are manufactured robotics has not yet taken any place in the industry whilst is has been the excepted norm for many years in the car industry. The production line has been relatively new development in the small craft and has not been taken up by number of small craft producers. The main drive behind this project is to find out how much the small craft industry can develop by looking at the car industry and seeing what aspects can be taken over and used efficiently to improve the production methods of pleasure craft.

bibo:shortTitle: Non destructive testing in small craft surveying.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project is to answer the question “ Is the small craft surveying profession using all the non-destructive testing (NDT) tools that have been developed to greatest effect and is there opportunity for further adoption?”

bibo:shortTitle: Impact of culture on perceptions of service quality: a comparative study of British and Arab hotel guests in Egypt
bibo:abstract:
This study is set within the context of the tourism and hospitality sector in Egypt, a popular and expanding tourism destination in the Middle East/North Africa. 
The study specifically investigates the impact of culture on
expectations and perceptions of service quality in hotels. In the literature it has been pointed out that there is a shortage of studies focusing on the impact of culture on service quality. What research has been done generally
indicates that expectations of service quality by an individual may vary according to whether that person is from a high or low power distance, and whether from a high context or low context, cultural background. With increasing competition in the hospitality sector service quality could be an important factor in gaining competitive advantage, and understanding cultural differences and can be helpful in dealing with customers from different
backgrounds.
Following a positivistic methodology and quantitative methods, an adapted version of the SERVQUAL questionnaire was administered to Arab and British hotel guests in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt. Consequently 504 correctly completed copies were analysed using hypotheses testing and correlation analysis. To the five dimensions of SERVQUAL- tangibles, empathy, responsiveness, assurance and reliability-a sixth dimension of sustainability was also added. This was a novel idea.  The findings showed that Arabs had, overall, lower expectations and perceptions of service quality than the British guests. This showed that there is a relationship between expectations of service quality and culture but that the finding could not be explained in terms of Hofstede’s cultural dimensions as the literature review generally suggests. Follow up interviews with hotel guests showed that the lower expectations of Arabs in general and Egyptians in particular, could be the result of their beliefs that Westerners are always treated better than Arabs by the hotel staff. The findings also show that environmentally friendly practices by hotels can be added as a dimension to SERVQUAL in respect of the hospitality sector.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 50ft cruiser racer.
bibo:abstract: Within the Marine Industry there has been a growing trend in the production of modern cruiser / racer designs which have been designed with high performance in mind. The performance however has been achieved in part at the expense of the cruising orientated luxuries of the vessel. It is felt that this type of vessel is being marketed towards an individual who relishes the thought of close, fast racing but would also require the capability to take the family coastal cruising and undertaking longer passages. Because of this the seaworthiness and comfort of the vessel are important aspects. The aim of the project was to design a vessel of approximately 50 feet in length which would be a fast and competitive racer but also a relatively easy and safe to handle, family cruiser. To achieve this an investigation into the use of modern honeycomb panels within the interior and the use of a lightweight carbon mast was carried out. The aim was to increase the overall performance and stability of the vessel by reducing the weight and lowering the centre of gravity but at the same time not losing the luxurious feel of a high quality family cruiser. This was achieved by producing two vessels based on the same hull but with varying weights and position centre of gravity. A computer generated stability program (Hydromax) was then used to study the changes in stability of the vessel. It was found that the range of stability rose by 18 % for the lighter weight vessel and its ability to right itself after capsize has increased by 11%. The performance gains were judged using a Velocity Production Program or V.P.P. and showed a potential speed increase resulting in an 18 second advantage on the original vessel over 1 nautical mile. The potential of repositioning the weight at the keel and increasing the overall sail area was also investigated.

bibo:shortTitle: A critical examination of the outpatient process in a National Health Service setting
"Dead" FRP yachts are a growing problem ; how can we recycle them?
bibo:abstract: The material FRP (Fibre Reinforced Plastics) was introduced to the yacht manufacturing industry in the early 1960’s. This material became rapidly more popular, as a building material, then the usual building materials such as steel, wood and aluminium. The reason behind this is that it is more durable then the traditional materials. New technologies have brought many benefits to the world. Along with these benefits come problems, one of which is the disposal of solid waste in a most environmental friendly way. At present, the disposal of old FRP boats is done either by: burning them, sinking the boats or they are put in landfill sites. These are easy and relatively cheap ways of disposing the “dead” FRP yachts, however it is not environmental friendly. The aim of this project is to find a method of recycling/ disposing “dead” FRP boats in a most environmental friendly way. This project was undertaken because it covers the interest of the author and the most important reason is that it has great future potential. Relevant information was extracted from the available literature. The information gathered both from this method and from contact with experts in the FRP recycling industry was then analysed in relation to the hypothesis. The analysis revealed the existence of reasonable environmental friendly methods, used by the car recycling industry, to recycle FRP scrap. These methods may well be adapted to dispose old FRP yachts. There are two main driving forces to recycle “dead” FRP yachts, which are regulations and economics. This report concludes that: the “Cradle to Grave” law, which has been imposed by the European Union for the automotive industry, should be enforced for the marine industry in the near future. Once this has been done, the FRP yacht manufacturing industry should adapt a similar recycling circle as the car manufacturing industry. Limitations due to the availability of data and literature has restricted this work, therefore it has been necessary to speculate to an extent, whilst being as subjective as possible. It is the recommendation of this work that further research is conducted in this field.

bibo:shortTitle: A comparison between propellor and waterjet propulsion.
bibo:abstract: For many years, the propulsion of vessels across the world has been the subject of much development and technological advance as knowledge of the subject has increased and an awareness of the need for faster and more economical drive types to compete in a modern society has grown. Propellers are extensively used worldwide, to power everything from small boats up to large cargo carriers and battleships, though in the last few decades, new propulsion methods have been developed, and compete in a market previously dominated by propeller propulsion. Waterjet propulsion has experienced a recent boom, and more and more craft are being powered by this system, for both leisure and commercial applications. As the need and popularity of maritime activities has grown however, so has the number of incidents requiring assistance from rescue services the world over. In the United Kingdom and Ireland, the Royal National Lifeboat Institution has made it its goal to provide the necessary emergency cover to seafarers and those in peril around our coasts, and has strived to design and create modern lifeboats to fulfill the changing role of a lifeboat service in the present day. In the early days, a major break though was seen to be the transition from sail and oar power to the combustion engine, and it has remained like this for a several decades, with some of the most recent vessels such as the Severn and Trent Class boats still being powered by conventional propeller propulsion. A break with a long tradition was hailed with the launch of two new boats, the E-class waterjet powered craft and a hover rescue vehicle in 2002, and future developments are for a new Fast Slipway Boat and the possible inclusion of waterjet powered craft with the current fleet of all weather boats. It is with this idea in mind that this project is undertaken, and focuses on installing a waterjet into an existing lifeboat hull, and using manufacturers literature and other maritime formulae to develop an idea of the vessels new condition and performance characteristics. Although the equations used provide an idea of how a conversion or installation such as this would effect the chosen vessel, it is unlikely that a transformation of this nature could be carried out using an existing hull, because of the exact requirements of waterjet selection using boat resistance and engine power/speed data, and the amount of work that would need to be carried out to modify the hull to accommodate the new system. For this reason, the future of waterjet propulsion in a specifically designed hull, and the benefits that can be provided by a waterjet propelled lifeboat will be addressed and examined to determine the possible future applications of a jet powered craft in an organisation such as the RNLI.

bibo:shortTitle: The advantages and disadvantages of introducing advanced composites into the civil industry.
bibo:abstract:
The following study provides an insight into two main area’s, these areas are the marine and the civil industries. These areas are becoming very similar with the use of advanced composites. The introduction and literature review explains how the project came too light through history of both industries, explaining what and how various materials have been used in the past, leading to advanced composites.
The main body of the report looks at the advantages and the disadvantages of using advanced composites in the civil industry. The advantages of using composites in the civil industry is backed up by a project that has already taken place as evidence to show that there are more advantages to composites in the industry than disadvantages.
The conclusion then highlights the areas that are of a benefit to the civil industry, and then highlights the areas that need to be dealt with, in order for the composite to be of a reasonable standard.

bibo:shortTitle: Utilising a community of practice approach to foster networks of pedagogic inquiry and enhance QL experiences across institutions
bibo:abstract: A community of practice (CoP) approach aims to create opportunities for the dissemination and development of best practice in teaching and learning and pedagogic inquiry by fostering multiple and overlapping communities of interested parties across the institution.  This session focuses on the issues and challenges involved in developing communities of pedagogic practice (CoPP).  The findings from a qualitative study of four leading practice institutions, with recently launched and/or established communities, are described.  Findings from a staff preference survey and initial first year experiences of ‘pump priming’ a CoPP at one HEI in the UK are discussed.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into whether undergraduates of Southampton Solent University Business School are influenced by a company's CSR activities when applying for graduate jobs

An investigation of the consumers’ perceptions towards the
MINI brand and an in-depth analysis and evaluation of the
company’s brand equity, with special focus on the brand
awareness factor
Impact of terrorism on economy and foreign investments; example of 9/11
Understanding the obstacles surrounding starting a new small business particularly in today’s difficult climate
An investigation of powerboat drive systems.
bibo:abstract:
Today there are hundreds of different luxury powerboats on the market to choose from between 10 and 30m. Amongst these boats, there are many different drive types in use, (namely; conventional shaft drive, outdrives, jetdrives and surface piercing drives). Some companies fit certain drive types as standard but quite a few leave the decision down the buyer. This can often be a difficult decision as not much ‘non-technical’ information is available on these different drive types.
An example of this is the Sunseeker SuperHawk 48’, which is currently available with twin outdrives, twin Arneson surface drives, triple outdrives or triple Trimax surface drives. Obviously, the decision is not going to be an easy one to make when considering the different performance, handling and economy characteristics of each installation, as well as the widely varying costs.
This problem can also be found in the commercial sector. Does a harbour master fit conventional drives for slow, economic easy handling or jet/surface drives for fast patrol work? Or even a combination of both?
Even on the racing circuit different systems can be seen to be used as each team believes that their opted system will be best suited for the boat and racing conditions.
This project investigates the different types of drive systems currently in use in the recreational powerboat market on craft between 10 and 20m in length.
Research was carried out into the history and development of the drive systems, gathering information from a wide variety of different sources.
It was found that jetdrives and surface drives are used widely in the commercial and racing industry but aren’t used very widely in the recreational craft market.
The main drives in use are sterndrives and conventional shaft drives.
The drives were analysed to consider its performance, cost, and running efficiency and fuel consumption.
A lack of available information made the analysis of jetdrives and surface drives difficult.
It was found that while the sterndrives in use proved better than shaft drives in all areas its physical capabilities restricted it to use in boats below 40ft.
It s thought that the current use of the drive systems is unlikely to change in the near future unless sterndrive manufacturers can improve the systems power-handling capabilities or peoples perception of jetdrives and surface drives being expensive and inefficient change dramatically over the next few years.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a day sailer for Mediterranean charter.
bibo:abstract:
This project was undertaken to fulfil the final year course requirements of the BSc (Hons) Degree in Yacht Manufacturing and Surveying at Southampton Institute.

The subject for the project “The Design of a Day Sailer for Mediterranean Charter” was chosen as there is a genuine demand for such a vessel from Sunsail, which is one of the World’s largest yacht charter companies. They are interested in replacing their fleet of ex-flotilla yachts, which are currently used for day sailing at their beach clubs, with a new vessel specifically designed to meet their requirements. 

Having been employed as a club/base manager for six years by Sunsail, the author had in-depth practical experience of managing the operation of the existing yachts.  This background also enabled direct access to Sunsail’s senior club management, who provided details of the problems with the current yachts and their requirements for the new design.

The main problems with the existing yachts is their high operational and maintenance costs, which is related to the fact that they were all originally fitted out and equipped for two week flotilla charters and therefore have all the fixtures and systems associated with cruising.  Also the fleet is made up of yachts from a number of manufacturers in a range of sizes, which increases the number of spare parts that need to be ordered/stored and complicates the maintenance program. 

The objectives for the new design were compliance with the relevant RCD and MCA legislation, be easy and safe to sail and have lower operating/maintenance cost than the current yachts.  These objectives have been achieved in the design of the Mediterranean Day Sailer (MDS), which meets all the client’s requirements.

bibo:shortTitle: Is using the material carbon fibre in the manufacture of yacht masts a viable option to aluminium?
bibo:abstract:
This report describes the advantages of using a carbon mast rather then an aluminium mast. There is a trend for that which high performance racing teams and classes use, other racing teams, classes and cruising yachts soon adopt. The method used to assess whether or not carbon masts are better then aluminium masts included using mathematical estimations for rig loads and rig construction. From this, a velocity prediction program could be created to estimate speed change and costing estimates could then be calculated. 
The results of the case study velocity prediction program were that using carbon fibre masts had three major effects on the model. Firstly, that the overall displacement was lower thus reducing the wetted surface area. The second effect was partly because of the first but as the mast was lighter there was a reduction in the vertical centre of gravity thus increasing the righting arm. The third effect was, that with a decrease in the surface area of the mast therefore improving in the aerodynamics of the yacht. Due to all these reasons the yachts with carbon fibre masts were notably quicker in all true wind directions except when the wind was at 180 degrees. Here there was less of a difference due to the higher surface area of the aluminium mast. 
The results of the costing study were partially inconclusive. As it was not necessarily 100% accurate due to problems of what costs should be included in the estimates and if so how many mast should the cost be set off against. But the results demonstrate that the cost of a carbon fibre mast is between 1.8 and 4.25 times the cost of an aluminium mast. Also the results indicated that even the most expensive masts were only 1.35% of the total cost of the yacht. Other activities that were included in the report were:
- A survey into the type of yachts that fitted carbon fibre masts
- An investigation into the techniques involved in manufacturing carbon fibre and aluminium masts.
- An investigation into the material properties of carbon fibre

bibo:shortTitle: Editorial
Hire purchase agreements: the unfortunate triumph of form over function
Illegality as a defence to negligence in English law
Civil liability for animals
Kit boat design.
bibo:abstract:
The current state of the marine industry is seeing many small production companies being forced into closure from severe lack custom. The decline in new boat purchase is not however reflected in the coastal leisure participation figures with recent studies still seeing increases in many areas. This indicates that there is still a demand for leisure craft, but the options available are not appropriate for a market where disposable income is not as readily available. Other options available to those still wishing to pursue their hobbies are to purchase a second hand vessel and hope to save as a result of the vessels deterioration, or to take on the daunting task a complicated home build project.

This project offers an alternative to all these options, supplying potential customers with brand new inshore power craft capable of being adapted to a wider range of activities and at a fraction of the price.

The project involves selecting an existing power craft and updating it to provide a simple kit boat to the market. The project will investigate the use of innovative new building techniques in an attempt to produce a vessel that is simple to produce and requires little or no boatbuilding experience. New production techniques such as CNC cutting and nesting will be researched in order to reduce wastage and overall cost, and modern materials that have been rarely used by amateurs in the past will be used to produce a light, durable structure. The final design will also be assessed for suitability and to ensure that the vessel and idea as a whole is in fact a viable investment and if this niche market can be exploited.

bibo:shortTitle: Is it viable to convert 'Ocean Phoenix 77' for luxury disabled access charter in unlimited operation?
bibo:abstract:
This paper will examine the feasibility of purchasing and converting the Rob Humphrey’s design Ocean Phoenix 77 (OP77) into a luxury, disabled access, blue water cruising yacht, which is able to operate in unlimited areas.
The vessel is presently for sale in the Mediterranean for offers around €2,900,000 and is reported to be in near new condition. Built by Hamble Yacht Services in 2002 her hull is built to American Bureau of Shipping (ABS) compliance and she is classed as Recreational Craft Directive (RCD) Category A with 3 watertight subdivisions which will not keep her afloat if her main saloon floods. The vessel is also just below the Large Yacht Code (LY2) code required minimum length.
The rules and guidelines of the relevant regulatory bodies will be examined and any loopholes and ramifications of these will be discussed.
The feasibility study will assess the suitability of the vessel against the most pertinent stability and structural classification criteria. In order to comply with Maritime Coastguard Agency (MCA) Small Commercial Vessel (SCV) unlimited operation requirements, the vessel will need to be fitted with at least one additional watertight subdivision to ensure compliance with the minimum freeboard requirement of 75mm should the integrity of any one compartment be affected.
The vessel’s suitability for the proposed usage will be examined as will the likely take up by disabled guests. The projected running costs and estimated price of conversion will establish a required financial return and the project will examine the possibility of a bespoke new build alternative.
The paper will assess the specific requirements of guests with disabilities and will focus on ensuring that the vessel is as manageable and comfortable as possible whilst ensuring their dignity and retaining a degree of versatility which will not alienate able bodied guests.
Access and safety are key issues and will be assessed with a view to making the vessel easier to operate for guests of differing abilities.
The General Arrangement (GA) will be assessed and two different configurations will be proposed which comply with classification requirements whilst offering versatility and ease of use to the widest range of abilities. This assessment will include the rig and sail control systems with a view to making them as user friendly as possible with minimum disruption and cost.
Stability and code compliance will be reassessed once precise details of the proposed alterations are known.
The range will be assessed regarding fuel and fresh water supplies and the vessel’s powering and propulsion will be assessed to ensure that the current arrangements are still suitable for the converted vessel.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 22m expedition sailing yacht for charter.
bibo:abstract:
The purpose of this student project was to design a 22m expedition sailing yacht for charter, capable of sailing in light ice conditions. Polar areas are extreme destinations
which require both specific design and equipment. The author intended to create a yacht that fulfils the requirements of an expedition vessel while meeting customers’ common demands in terms of sailing, adventure and ecology.
First a parametric study was carried out to determine a design guideline and fix the main characteristics. Then the hull was developed based on the parameters previously
established and the author‘s understanding of naval architecture. The boat had to comply with general needs in terms of accommodation space, sailing capacity and also
with minimum stability criteria.
The general arrangement was an essential factor of the target design. Practical considerations leaded the interior design, which should be comfortable and sheltered.
Because of the yacht program, sail ability and stability were the key words when establishing the sail plan. Likewise low draft appendages were based on practical
solutions well used in the nautical industry.
The sailing balance was also demonstrated and a velocity prediction was carried out using WinVPP TM.
From a construction point of view, the choice of the hull material was based on the author’s research. Steel was briefly compared to aluminium alloy before determining
which metal was the most suitable.
Scantlings and basic structure were established using Gerr’s method and following the International Standard Organisation (ISO) regulations.
Looking at ice-class rules and similar expedition vessels, ice capability was taken into
account by adding structural reinforcements.
The mast, rigging and spreaders design was done using a basic forces resolution.
Systems and engineering details such as the engine installation and the tank’s position were preliminary designed.
Once all the scantlings and the layouts finalised, it was possible to carry out the weight estimation and to finalise the stability calculations.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a new Class 9.50 sailboat.
bibo:abstract:
This final year project aims to produce a preliminary design for a Class 9.50bsailboat.
The Class 9.50 is a brand new single-handed offshore racing yachts class. At present few yachts have been designed, only a couple is under construction.
The interest has been driven by the author wishes to produce a reasonable size sailing yacht allowing the possibility to work on almost all components of the design
process. These wishes have been reinforced by the investigation into the design choices by limiting the existing designs influence due to the Class 9.50 new existence.
Research has been carried out in order to valid design choices and overcome any issues raised and encountered during the project. The solutions following here are based
on the author skills, knowledge learned during this course and own experience.
This report presents the design choices and decisions made, the methods used and the calculations as well as the issues raised, their solutions, all along the design process.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design for a harbour tug with fire fighting option.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project is to carry out the preliminary design for a fire fighting harbor tug able to take part in towing big ships but also capable of providing good fire fighting responses. As mentioned previously the towing industry requires vessels able to react in emergency situations such as fire at sea. This project is a good opportunity to learn more about this very interesting and fast moving industry.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 40ft charter catamaran "the Freerider" with special reference to a novel stepped hull.
bibo:abstract: This project is based on an existing demand coming from the holidays centre for a day charter to one week trip boat. That imposes many requirements for the boat to be accessible, comfortable and safe. To meet the requests, a catamaran of 40ft is designed with a novel stepped hull. The objective of this project is to establish the preliminary design on the first part and then use it a base for more studies on different elements. Once the preliminary design is achieved, the first research established is on the behaviour of the steps in waves via the towing tank and the wave maker. The measurements obtained are tricky to interpret and others tools are used to help on the conclusion. Finally, the measurements obtained are not reliable and cannot be used further. Nevertheless, the video taken onboard helps to improve the shape of the steps to reduce the drag. Then for the mast, a complete study is achieved on the rig forces. As the tension on the diamonds cannot be calculated statically, a Finite Element Analysis is carried out to determine the applied tension on each wire and then select the correct diameter. For credible results, the analysis is established step by step which validates the computer model with reality. Via the tank testing, different daggerboards can be tested and compared. The efficiency of an end plate can then be analysed and compared to a conventional one. The results show that the end plate diminishes the yaw angle but generates a bit more drag. For a practical reason, the end plate is kept for the design. Finally, a FEA study is achieved on the crossbeam structure including the rig effect. The simple computer model without the mast is first verified comparing the hand calculations with the results obtained. The final scantling is quite simple and need a complete investigation on the best profile with the best material to obtain the best compromise

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 35 foot short handed yacht with both cruising and racing specification.
An investigation into the variation of the tensile properties of epoxy resin with colloidal silica.
bibo:abstract:
This project was undertaken to highlight the issues of the change in tensile strength of epoxy resin with the addition of varying volumes of colloidal silica. The information found in the body of this project is valuable to the boat building industry by giving greater understanding of the bonding strength of “slurry” mixes when bonding items such as composite washers onto uneven, curved or angled surfaces, where the viscosity of the epoxy resin needs to be increased to create a satisfactory bond.

This investigation is concerned in the strength of the epoxy-colloidal silica fusion, and not the strength of the join between the bonding surface and the bonding medium. To test this, identical blocks of varying volumes of colloidal silica and epoxy resin were created and tensile tested using a Lloyds LR 30K tensile testing machine to measure the tensile strength properties. 

The results collected show a dramatic decrease in strength with the increase in the percentage of volume of colloidal silica.

bibo:shortTitle: A design of a luxury 70ft sailing yacht with dive boat / tender.
bibo:abstract: This project is to produce a design solution from a specification by a fictitious client. It is intended to replicate a common scenario found in the yacht design industry. The brief was to design an aluminium hulled yacht to accommodate a family of four plus guests and provide facilities for SCUBA diving with an integral garage for the tender. Aesthetics were important to the client, who expressed a desire for uncluttered decks and sleek lines. The yacht needed to be capable of being sailed short handed. In this case, the client is both the author and the designer and the design is loosely based around his interests. The type of yacht chosen was seen to be more challenging from a designer’s point of view as apposed to a racing yacht, for example, where there are fewer compromises and design decisions are clearer cut. The project began with research into tenders and dive boats as garaging, combined with accommodation for eight passengers would determine the general arrangement and size of the vessel. The process was carried out this way as client had not specified the length of the yacht, but its practical requirements. From this a study was carried out on vessels of the appropriate size and the initial parametrics were produced and the design spiral started. The finished design was for a seventy foot yacht, 15 foot wide. It included a stern garage for the tender, also housing the liferaft and compressor. To double cabins with en-suites and two single cabins with additional ‘Pullman’ berths and a shared head were arranged as close to amidships as possible. This reduced seaway accelerations, creating a layout that was both practical and comfortable for passengers. A large galley and saloon was placed on the port side. A two-rudder configuration was selected to counter balance the problems associated with the wide flat hull. Other specific design features included: - a self tacking jib and automated sailing controls. A safety survey of the craft was undertaken and full range of safety features were incorporated into the design. Challenges of this design included the general arrangement and the logistics of fitting a large tender into a comparatively small boat. Performance from the specified metal hull needed to be enhanced without compromising safety or comfort, whilst all the time maintaining an aesthetically pleasing design

bibo:shortTitle: 24 metre modern classic charter yacht.
bibo:abstract:
This project set out to design a 24 metre modern classic charter yacht based upon an investigation into the desirable characteristics of traditional off-shore yachts. The aesthetics, performance and seaworthy characteristics that may be incorporated into a modern design were considered. The design priorities of comfort, aesthetics, performance and intended use have been off-set to develop the best overall design. A parametric study was completed,
grouping yachts into four categories to enable a comparison of trends between a range of hull forms and sail plans. The results of this study have influenced design decisions for
different components of the yacht.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of an ORC GP42 racing yacht.
bibo:abstract: The ORC GP42 class was launched as part of the new ORC Level Class in August 2005. Following the success of the TP52 class, the smaller and more affordable GP42 is expected to help reinvigorate the Grand Prix racing seen which has been so inactive since the demise of the old IOR ton classes. The aim of this project was to design a GP42 targeted at the Mediterranean racing circuit. The design process started with the development of a base hull, appendage package, sailplan and detailed weight estimation. This provided the grounds on which to carry out a VPP study in order to evaluate a range of parametric hull variations. The extremely high sail area – displacement ratio of these yachts is likely to result in a performance not dissimilar to that of a TP52. It is unlikely that the standard VPP force model will accurately predict the resistance characteristics of these boats, which are expected to make the jump into the planing mode downwind. As a result it was decided that a full matrix of tank test runs (upright and heeled and yawed) should be carried out with a view to creating a design-specific VPP. This was achieved using the Wolfson Experimental Method (WUX), where tank test data was regressed to define the resistance characteristics of the yacht over a range of operating speeds and conditions. Unfortunately due to very steep induced drag factor slopes, possibly brought on by appendage flutter, there were difficulties obtaining reasonable heel and induced drag WUX coefficients. While it was felt that the coefficients were not wholly reliable, VPP predictions from the experimental force model were compared with predictions from the standard force model and with a second experimental model derived from the VPP’s own resistance predictions for the tank test runs. The experimental model derived from the tank data did not provide a reliable source on which to carry out further analysis, but enough insight was gained through observations made during the tank sessions and from the initial VPP study from which to develop a final design.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a wheelchair accessible sailing yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The main aim of this project is to design a sailing yacht that will accommodate people with disabilities, this will include wheelchair users, in an over night situation. To do this the project will look at:
• Other yachts that have been adapted for wheelchair users.
• The ergonomics of a wheelchair, and how this can be successfully manoeuvred through the interior of a yacht, and its facilities.
• MCA requirements regarding yachts being used in sailing schools, and rules governing the safety of disabled people onboard.
• Necessary equipment for other types of disability.
• How the yacht will perform in terms of stability and sea keeping.
• Materials and structure of the yacht.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a 15 metre trawler style flybridge motor yacht with an investigation into the potential use of propeller tunnels.
bibo:abstract:
This project was undertaken as part fulfillment of the degree of Yacht and Powercraft Design (BEng) at Southampton Solent University. The project developed the design of a 15-metre, trawler-style flybridge motor yacht in addition to researching the potential use of propeller tunnels on the design hull.
Trawler-style motor yachts are traditionally designed with long-distance cruising in mind and as such are typically round-bilge displacement or semi-displacement type hulls. There are however, a number of higher performance trawler-style motor yachts on the market aimed at weekend and shorter range cruising. These are produced by manufacturers such as Grand Banks, Hardy Marine, Seaward, Beneteau and Nimbus.
This project centered around designing a similar higher performance hull in conjunction with an investigation into the potential use of propeller tunnels or pockets on such a hull. Tunnels or pockets have been and are used on several types of motor vessel including Tyne-class lifeboats, recreational motor yachts, commercial launches and naval vessels. There are several reasons for their use including draft reduction, increased propeller diameter (potential efficiency benefits), and reducing shaft angle (increased potential engine location options and thrust improvements).
This report includes a tow tank investigation into the effect of propeller tunnels on hull drag alone, through comparison of two exact scale models. The models were constructed from GRP, one with tunnels and one without, from a GRP female mould taken from a similar style model hull. These models were then tow tank tested through a relevant speed range to compare resistance, heave and trim behaviour.
The results indicated that up until the maximum design speed required by the brief, the use of partial propeller tunnels provided a small beneficial drag effect. Further in-depth results analysis and propeller efficiency research is provided within this report. However, on the basis of these results, a decision was taken to incorporate tunnel pockets into the design hull.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 12 metre GRP power catamaran.
Design of a Transpac 52
bibo:abstract: The purpose of this project is to design a Transpac 52. She is a fast monohull keelboat; a box rule and the International Measurement System control her construction. The design will follow the design spiral that starts with the parametric studies. The Transpac 52 is a new class, nevertheless a lot of boats were built and a lot of information is available. These parametrics could be used to make a basic lines plan. The biggest variable with the hull design is over waterline beam, this variable must be analyzed according to the Velocity Prediction Program. The overall length of the yacht is set by the rule that leaves the freedom to choose the length of the waterline by finding the best balance of aft overhang and transom immersion. Weight saving is a high priority, so the structure weight estimation must be accurate. The structure design has to follow the ABS regulation; and it has to be light and strong, consequently the material chosen to make the hull can be carbon prepreg and nomex core.

bibo:shortTitle: Rigid inflatable boats are built in many different ways, is there a reason for this? Is this due to cost, speed of manufacture or technique?
bibo:abstract:
This project has been undertaken because there has been a noticeable change in the style of the inflatable collars and the tube attachment methods that are used on Rigid Inflatable Boats (R.I.B’s). As changes have occurred to the trend it has been decided to investigate into possible reasons for why this has happened.
The author has been working part time in the RIB industry for over five years on a part time basis and has seen many different makes and models. He has been involved in the majority of parts that make up RIB manufacture and repair. He has primarily been involved in the leisure industry and worked for one of the largest rib sales and service companies in the UK.
The methods that are going to be used in this project are a time study and a cost analysis. Two similar sized boats will be used and compared in many ways with consideration to the technique used to make them, the speed of the build and the cost, using both material and labour cost.
This project also focuses mainly on the Hypalon tube side of the industry. This is due to the variety of construction types and styles that can be used with this material, which is where the trend was noticed.
Several companies where visited, and the information from these visits were used to produce a time and cost study.
This study found that the sectional style tube had an 8-hour shorter build time than the sectional.
It also proved that the sectional style tube uses less material. It is therefore cheaper in material cost when based on a m2 study. The seamless style produces more wastage due to the intricate and banana shape of the tube.
As the seamless style has a shorter build time than the sectional style it was cheaper in labour cost.
These results proved that the change from sectional to seamless has been because of a shorter production time and a lower material and labour cost. There were also other factors for the change that unfortunately could not be proved, such as the argument for aesthetics.

bibo:shortTitle: An evaluation of chopped strand mat and woven roving.
bibo:abstract:
This project was undertaken with an interest in the fact that boat building materials and manufacturing processes have been improving over the years, however recently there has been a definite decrease in the amount of new technology being used in production boat building. The aim then was to determine the reasons for this, and namely, to investigate why stitched fabrics are not being used more widely throughout the production boat building industry. Attention was drawn firstly to the design of composite structures using these reinforcements, followed by the manufacturing processes used to apply them. Consideration was given to any barriers to new technology, including any health and safety drawbacks and structural issues. Test panels were then constructed, one of each reinforcement type, Chopped Strand Mat and Woven Roving, Double Bias stitched fabric, and Quadriaxial stitched fabric. These panels were then cut into samples and tested for flexural properties and fibre content at the Southampton Solent University Test Labs. Using the obtained mechanical properties a case study was then carried out using Lloyds Register Special Service Craft software, investigating design with both in plane and flexural properties, which then lead onto discussion as to stiffness, thickness, mass and cost.
From the investigation it was concluded that stitched fabrics are not used more widely in the production boat building industry because the budget does not allow for the amount of design work required to use the reinforcements to their full potential, or the cost of the reinforcement itself. Furthermore, CSM / WR produces a laminate almost as stiff as the stitched equivalent, builds up thickness more quickly due to the lower fibre content, and requires much less design work as it is so established. Classification societies require a certain thickness, however this is governed by robustness, and therefore the ability to build up thickness is desirable. Stitched fabrics increase mechanical properties, however the thickness required to pass criteria requires several more layers than CSM / WR, and the stresses in a hull structure are relatively low.

bibo:shortTitle: Hypothetical analysis of optimum boatyard production systems.
bibo:abstract:
Effective production control is essential for the successful manufacture of cost effective products within a commercial enterprise. This report will investigate the factors that affect production and identify ‘optimum’ management systems that can be implemented in the hypothetical production of 26’ GRP fishing vessels.
Current information from primary and secondary research sources will be analysed to identify management techniques that may be applied to achieve optimised production. Production planning methods will be applied hypothetically to achieve the economic allocation of labour resources.
This report proposes management techniques that are suitable to controlling the major cost drivers associated with this hypothetical application. The production planning identifies specific problems and suggests means by which they can be resolved.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 21m express charter yacht.
bibo:abstract: The reason for undertaking this particular project stems from my personal interest in practical yacht design where the end product is accessible to a large audience. Racing yacht design is a great medium for testing and developing new theories or designs but very few people have access to the vessels. My design philosophy is to create a yacht which has been produced for the recreational user whilst utilising modern advancements in naval architecture. I aim to produce a vessel which can be manufactured economically from cost-effective materials but is still capable of performance to excite. I aim to utilise the current methods available to small yachts designers, it is not my intension to use CFD or towing tank research. Although this can be accurate and enable extreme design philosophies to be tested the financial implications can be far too high for a small design company to use. All the methods utilised can be adopted with little expense, any CAD or other computational methods will be using programs available in all established design offices.

bibo:shortTitle: 37' performance day boat.
bibo:abstract: The boat the author is going to deal with in this personal project is a 37 feet Performance Day Boat. This is a both sporty and family motorboat, which is able to achieve high speeds, but also to provide very good conditions of comfort when running at sea and also when mooring in a creek. Therefore, good stability, clever layout and good sea keeping are required. The boat will be mainly used for coastal navigation, but some offshore navigation is also possible, as the boat complies with category A requirements.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 12m stylish cruiser racer yacht.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project was developed the full design of cruiser racer yacht with stylish design as priority. The purpose of the yacht was to be mainly a cruiser, but also IMS Rules and Regulations had been considered. The length had to be sufficiently large to have a volume inside for 6 peoples. A small market analysis was done to try to know what the customers want for a sail cruiser now and in the near future.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 40' offshore racer compliant with the class 40 rule.
bibo:abstract: This project aims to establish an advanced design proposal for a Class 40 yacht.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a custom 60' cruising yacht for short-handed sailing combining luxury, style and high performance.
bibo:abstract: The aim of the project is to produce the design of a modern, family, ocean cruising yacht. The unique selling point of the yacht will be its contemporary design. The interior will be a minimalist, fresh yet practical space, providing high luxury whilst maintaining safety at sea.

bibo:shortTitle: 8m trailable sport boat.
bibo:abstract: Nowadays, fast sailing boats are getting very advanced and very expensive. This dissertation aims to design a performance sailing boat 'Kenarize' with the best compromise between price and efficiency.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a transpac 52 race yacht.
bibo:abstract: This project is to design a racing yacht that conforms to the TP52 rules, and is optimised for European conditions and courses.

bibo:shortTitle: 15m steel 'rule-beating' fishing vessel.
bibo:abstract: This report outlines the initial design of a 15m steel ‘rule-beating’ fishing vessel. After investigation of the UK fishing industry the project became far more focused on the key issues of design. The necessary rules and regulations have been used so as to fulfill as many as possible of the safety issues required in one of the most dangerous industries in the UK. The design process undertook analysis of fishing operations, internal capacities, powering and range. From this a design was carried forward so that tank testing could be undertaken to gain an appreciation of the resistance and seakeeping abilities of these types of vessel.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary deisgn of a 35ft cruising trimaran.
BEC 65' Mediterranean fast motor yacht.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project was to produce a Mediterranean fast motor yacht.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a luxury performance sailing superyacht.
bibo:abstract: The purpose of this Project is to design a 90 foot luxury performance sailing superyacht.

bibo:shortTitle: Mini 6.5 with CTR keel system.
bibo:abstract: The objective of this work is the creation of a Mini Transat 6.50 racing boat. This boat has to meet the Class requirements which establish a “box rule” for the hull design (See The Rules section). With a maximum length this little boat is placed as the smallest ocean racing boat this makes it a highly sophisticated machine; many new systems are tried in these boats to then be applied to bigger open boats. These new developments range from twin rudders to asymmetric daggerboards, canting keels and huge rotating bowspits. In this project a 3D rotational system will be evaluated, this system is made up of a keel which is allowed to cant, rotate and be trimmed. This system has been originally created by the French designer Lucas, which allowed me to use his principle to create a new system to be evaluated in this work.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of shorthand performance cruising yacht.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project was to design a performance cruising yacht for a specific design brief that was submitted by an imaginary client. In the design process there was an attempt to complete as many rounds in the design spiral in order to refine the design.

bibo:shortTitle: Open 30 development.
bibo:abstract: This project intends to develop a preliminary design of an Open 30, which belongs to a new offshore sailing rule.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 36ft fast cruising catamaran.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project was to gain a better understanding of multihull design which involves different structural loads and other hydrodynamic considerations. Although multihull literature is poor, because of the lack of research on this type of boats, several parts of monohull theories can be applied to help the designer.

bibo:shortTitle: Yapado 43.
The preliminary design of an Open 60' IMOCA, with a special comparative study on hydrodynamic performances.
bibo:abstract:
The general purpose is the preliminary design of a safe and high competitive Open 60 solo racing yacht to the IMOCA class rules 2004. The project covers some subjects at a preliminary level and is focused on a special research study.
The aim of the study is to investigate the possible improvements of the underwater parts in terms of hydrodynamic Lift to Drag ratio. The investigation has
involved the use of the towing tank for comparative analysis.
The comparative study has demonstrated that the hull drag can be reduced when heeling, by sailing at an optimised negative leeway angle rather than actual positive leeway angles.
To achieve negative leeway angles, first of all the canting keel needs a second degree of freedom for keel angle of attack adjustment, secondly, the daggerboard needs to create more lift than usual.
Finally, it was found that the induced drag from the hull could be reduced, the induced drag from the daggerboard would then be increased, but the overall boat drag would be reduced for a given side force. Therefore the overall Lift to Drag ratio can be increased.

bibo:shortTitle: Fun design cruiser 34'.
bibo:abstract: The main objective of this design project is to respond to the requirements of the twenty-five to thirty years old young workers generation, and fulfil there requirements in terms of yachting. As they are young workers their budget is limited, yet they are full of energy. Therefore it was tried to design a relatively simple and cheap boat that is different from the ones already existing on the market by presenting some innovative solutions.

bibo:shortTitle: A preliminary design of a one-design club racing yahct.
bibo:abstract: The basic aim of this project is to create a yacht that best fulfils the specific design brief. This brief called for a one-design racing yacht primarily for use on the south coast of Ireland but one which would be suitable for any local sailing club racing scene. It is to be sailed by a crew of four to five people, generally in typical “round the cans” type racing. It needs to be an exiting boat to sail with good racing performance in the varied weather conditions typical of the south coast of Ireland but it must not require a crew of experts. In this way the boat will appeal to sailors of varied skill levels.

bibo:shortTitle: [Preliminary design of high speed luxury powercraft...]
bibo:abstract:
The design of a high speed luxury powercraft should firstly, as with all design projects, meet the needs of the client and the specification.
Attention should be given to the ergonomic and aesthetic aspects of the vessel; if the design were for military or commercial use, factors such as cost and speed of production might steer the design process. As the target market for the design will be wealthy “pleasure seekers”, cost and construction time will be shelved at the preliminary stages of the design.
The project aims to produce designs worthy of the modern market. Vessels of this size and finish have been produced and sold for decades, however it is only recently that industry advances have allowed for 20m luxury production motor yachts to begin reaching higher end speeds. The design will enter a position in a potentially very popular market.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a Volvo 70.
bibo:abstract: The objective of this report was to conduct the preliminary design for a Volvo 70. This was undertaken using yacht design principles and various analysis tools.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary deisgn of a sailing scientific research catamaran.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this dissertation was to create a sailing scientific research vessel.

bibo:shortTitle: Viability report of re-developing 25ft (8m) sports-boat and putting back into production.
bibo:abstract:
The reason for the project being undertaken is because the owner of the company, Talisman, came to the author asking for a report on reviving a project and modifying the vessel concerned. The points to look in to would be;
o Engines
o Wheelhouse modification
o Performance and stability
o Recreational Craft Directive Implications
o Any conclusions and recommendations made

The methods used to complete the project are a wide variety of skills ranging from working in the field taking first hand data straight form the vessel to designing and calculating images and data on a computer.
The main findings were, the vessel would be best suited remaining with a single engine instalment on a shaft drive due to cost and general style of vessel.
The wheelhouse became an aesthetically pleasing one to look at when considered who it was designed towards. This would be built out of a sandwich lay-up for strength and weight aspects
As for performance and Stability, the general performance is as good as can be expected, with a few modifications to the shaft angle and weight the Talisman will perform very well against it’s competitors. Stability of the Talisman was deemed adequate, the cabin/ galley, is too large, the volume of this area needs to be reduced to make sure she dose not submerge too much when this compartment is flooded.

bibo:shortTitle: Qualitative Methods for Classifying and Detecting Online Identity Deception
bibo:abstract: The overall aim of our research is to use qualitative methods to help understand online identity deception. In this position paper, two pilot studies are described. The first was designed to test the feasibility of using content analysis of online discussions to classify the perceptions of the ‘net generation’ regarding different levels of identity deception. Based on the classifications identified, the second follow-up study will use face-to-face focus groups to collect further thoughts on these classifications, and the new data will be presented at this CHI Workshop. It is hoped that the feedback at the Workshop will help to direct further research using qualitative methods to analyse naturally-occurring identity descriptions found on social networking sites. The overall outcome of the research programme is to produce a set of indicators to assist identity deception in online environments.

bibo:shortTitle: Software Defect Association Mining and Defect Correction Effort Prediction
bibo:abstract: Abstract—Much current software defect prediction work focuses on the number of defects remaining in a software system. In this paper, we present association rule mining based methods to predict defect associations and defect correction effort. This is to help developers detect software defects and assist project managers in allocating testing resources more effectively. We applied the proposed methods to the SEL defect data consisting of more than 200 projects over more than 15 years. The results show that, for defect association prediction, the accuracy is very high and the false-negative rate is very low. Likewise, for the defect correction effort prediction, the accuracy for both defect isolation effort prediction and defect correction effort prediction are also high. We compared the defect correction effort prediction method with other types of methods—PART, C4.5, and Naıve Bayes and show that accuracy has been improved by at least 23 percent. We also evaluated the impact of support and confidence levels on prediction accuracy, false negative rate, false-positive rate, and the number of rules. We found that higher support and confidence levels may not result in higher prediction accuracy, and a sufficient number of rules is a precondition for high prediction accuracy.

bibo:shortTitle: Structured Reflection Facilitates Metacognitive Awareness and Learning
bibo:abstract: Many students in Higher Education (HE) struggle with the concept of reflective practice, hence they do not engage well with the process and its full value is seldom realised. Using a simple software system developed to facilitate and structure the recording, storage and retrieval of reflections, students were able to monitor their development, resulting in improved metacognition. Students reported feeling empowered and perceived their learning had been enhanced since using the system.

bibo:shortTitle: An Analysis of Data Sets Used to Train and Validate Cost Prediction Systems
bibo:abstract:
OBJECTIVE - the aim of this investigation is to build up
a picture of the nature and type of data sets being used to
develop and evaluate different software project effort prediction systems. We believe this to be important since there is a growing body of published work that seeks to assess different prediction approaches. Unfortunately, results – to date – are rather inconsistent so we are interested in the extent to which this might be explained by different data sets.
METHOD - we performed an exhaustive search from 1980
onwards from three software engineering journals for research papers that used project data sets to compare cost
prediction systems.
RESULTS - this identified a total of 50 papers that used, one or more times, a total of 74 unique project data sets. We observed that some of the better known and publicly accessible data sets were used repeatedly making them potentially disproportionately influential. Such data sets also tend to be amongst the oldest with potential problems of obsolescence. We also note that only about 70% of all data sets are in the public domain and this can be particularly problematic when the data set description is incomplete or limited. Finally, extracting relevant information from research papers has been time consuming due to different styles of presentation and levels of contextural information.
CONCLUSIONS - we believe there are two lessons to learn.
First, the community needs to consider the quality and appropriateness of the data set being utilised; not all data sets are equal. Second, we need to assess the way results are presented in order to facilitate meta-analysis and whether a standard protocol would be appropriate.
