bibo:shortTitle:
Looking at Comparisons of Regression and Analogy-based
Software Project Cost Prediction
bibo:abstract:
OBJECTIVE – This paper builds on our previous research in which we found inconsistency within and between
results in empirical studies of software engineering cost estimation which had compared regression and analogy
techniques. To this end, this paper aims to determine why and how these inconsistencies occur. In addition, we
attempt to provide a solution which might reduce inconsistencies in future.
METHOD – We retrieved a sample of 11 journal papers and 9 conference papers which compared both regression and analogy-based prediction methods. Analysis of these papers uncovered inconsistencies within and between results. From this starting point we concluded that researchers should look beyond asking “What is the best prediction system?” Thus we now consider the reasons for these seemingly conflicting results.
RESULTS – We found little consistency between studies both methodologically and in terms of outcome.
CONCLUSIONS – We propose that researchers adopt more rigorous and uniform protocols when empirically
investigating project cost prediction methods and interpreting the results.

bibo:shortTitle: The Consistency of Empirical Comparisons of Regression and Analogy-based Software Project Cost Prediction
bibo:abstract:
OBJECTIVE - to determine the consistency within and
between results in empirical studies of software
engineering cost estimation. We focus on regression and analogy techniques as these are commonly used.
METHOD – we conducted an exhaustive search using
predefined inclusion and exclusion criteria and identified 67 journal papers and 104 conference papers. From this sample we identified 11 journal papers and 9 conference papers that used both methods.
RESULTS – our analysis found that about 25% of studies were internally inconclusive. We also found that there is approximately equal evidence in favour of, and against analogy-based methods.
CONCLUSIONS – we confirm the lack of consistency
in the findings and argue that this inconsistent pattern
from 20 different studies comparing regression and analogy is somewhat disturbing. It suggests that we need to ask more detailed questions than just: “What is the best prediction system?”

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation of machine learning based prediction systems
bibo:abstract:
Traditionally, researchers have used either of-the-shelf models such as COCOMO, or developed local models using statistical techniques such as stepwise regression, to obtain software effort estimates. More recently, attention has turned to a variety of machine learning methods such as artifcial neural networks (ANNs), case-based reasoning (CBR) and rule induction (RI). This paper outlines some comparative research into the use of these three machine learning methods to build software eort prediction
systems. We briefly describe each method and then apply the techniques to a dataset of 81 software projects derived from a Canadian software house in the late 1980s. We compare the prediction systems in terms of three factors: accuracy, explanatory value and configurability. We show that ANN methods have superior accuracy and that RI methods are least accurate. However, this view is somewhat counteracted by problems with explanatory value and configurability. For example, we found that considerable
effort was required to configure the ANN and that this compared very unfavourably with the other techniques, particularly CBR and least squares regression (LSR). We suggest that further work be carried out, both to further explore interaction between the enduser and the prediction system, and also to facilitate configuration, particularly of ANNs.

bibo:shortTitle: Using meta-reflection to enhance performance
How technology can facilitate students’ reflective practice
bibo:abstract: Reflective practice, engaging with experience, reflecting-in and reflecting-on action (Schön 1983) develops new understanding and leads to persona-l and professional development (e.g. Moon, 1999). Reflective practitioners are able to self-regulate and monitor their progress. Reflecting on what was learned can help students become more aware of their own thought processes (McCrindle and Christensen 1995), but reflecting on how it was learned, metacognition (Flavell 1978) offers far greater benefits. There exists mounting evidence for the benefits of metacognition in relation to enhanced performance and academic success (e.g. Coutinho 2007; Dunning et al. 2003). However, despite the costly time investment incurred by recording reflections in journals, reflections are more often retrieved from memory than from the written word. Thus the retrieved reflection is subject to the fallibility of human memory (e.g. Baddeley 1999, p.275): distortion, embellishment or forgetting. Furthermore, despite evidence demonstrating that when learners know reflections are to be read, graded or assessed by others, the incentive is to demonstrate knowledge and hide ignorance or doubt (Boud and Walker 1998), students’ reflections in HE are typically assessed.  Dewey’s original purpose of reflection was to consider and strive to overcome weaknesses. In fact, Boud (1999) highlights the dichotomies between the nature of reflection and the nature of assessment, and questions the value and integrity of assessing reflective practice at all.

bibo:shortTitle: An Empirical Analysis of Software Productivity
bibo:abstract:
The aim of our research is to discover what factors impact software project productivity (measured as function points per hour) using real world data. Within this overall goal we also compare productivity between different business sectors and project types. We analysed a data set of almost 700 projects that have been collected by STTF from a number of Finnish companies since 1978. These projects are quite diverse type (new and maintenance projects), in terms of
size (6 to over 5000 function points), effort (55 to over 60000 person hours), application domain and implementation technology. There are three main findings. First productivity varies enormously between projects. Second, project type has limited influence on productivity. Third,
application domain or business area has a major impact upon productivity. Because this data set is not a random sample generalisation is somewhat problematic, we hope that it contributes to an overall body of knowledge about software productivity and thereby facilitates the construction of a bigger picture.

bibo:shortTitle: Using Grey Relational Analysis to Predict Software Effort with Small Data Sets
bibo:abstract:
The inherent uncertainty of the software development process
presents particular challenges for software effort prediction. We need to systematically address missing data values, feature subset selection and the continuous evolution of predictions as the project unfolds, and all of this in the context of data-starvation and noisy data. However, in this paper, we particularly focus on feature subset selection and effort prediction at an early stage of a project. We propose a novel approach of using Grey Relational Analysis (GRA) of Grey System Theory (GST), which is a recently developed system engineering theory based on the uncertainty of small samples. In this work we address some of the theoretical challenges in applying GRA to feature subset selection and effort prediction, and then evaluate our approach on five publicly available industrial data sets using stepwise regression as a benchmark. The results are very encouraging in the sense of being comparable or better than other machine learning techniques and thus indicate that the method has considerable potential.

bibo:shortTitle: Understanding object feature binding through experimentation as a precursor to modelling
bibo:abstract: In order to explore underlying brain mechanisms and to further understand how and where object feature binding occurs, psychophysical data are analysed and will be modelled using an attractor network. This paper describes psychophysical work and an outline of the proposed model. A rapid serial visual processing paradigm with a post-cue response task was used in three experimental conditions: spatial, temporal and spatio-temporal. Using a ‘staircase’ procedure, stimulus onset asynchrony for each observer for each condition was set in practice trails to achieve ~50% error rates. Results indicate that spatial location information helps bind objects features and temporal location information hinders it. Our expectation is that the proposed neural model will demonstrate a binding mechanism by exhibiting regions of enhanced activity in the location of the target when presented with a partial post-cue. In future work, the model could be lesioned so that neuropsychological phenomena might be exhibited. In such a way, the mechanisms underlying object feature binding might be clarified.

bibo:shortTitle: An Investigation of Rule Induction Based Prediction Systems
bibo:abstract: Traditionally, researchers have used either off-the-shelf models such as COCOMO, or developed local models using statistical techniques such as stepwise regression, to predict software effort estimates. More recently, attention has turned to a variety of machine learning methods such as artificial neural networks (ANNs), case-based reasoning (CBR) and rule induction (RI). This position paper outlines some preliminary research into the use of rule induction methods to build software cost models. We briefly describe the use of rule induction methods and then apply the technique to a dataset of 81 software projects derived from a Canadian software house in the late 1980s. We show that RI methods tend to be unstable and generally predict with quite variable accuracy. Pruning the feature set, however, has a significant impact upon accuracy. We also compare our results with a prediction system based upon a standard regression procedure. We suggest that further work is carried out to examine the effects of the relationships among, and between, the features of the attributes on the generated rules in an attempt to improve on current prediction techniques and enhance our understanding of machine learning methods.

bibo:shortTitle: Picture radio: will pictures with the change to digital, transform radio?
bibo:abstract:
This work looking at radio over the last 80 years and digital radio today will consider picture radio, one way that the recently introduced DAB1 terrestrial digital radio could be used.
Chapter one considers the radio history including early picture radio and television, plus shows how radio has come from the crystal set, with one pair of headphones, to the mains powered wireless with built in speakers. These radios became the main family entertainment in the home until television takes over that role in the mid 1950s. Then radio changed to a portable medium with the coming of transistor radios, to become the personal entertainment
medium it is today. 
Chapter two and three considers the new terrestrial digital mediums of DAB and DRM2 plus how it works, what it is capable of plus a look at some of the otherdigital radio platforms. 
Chapter four examines how sound is perceived by the listener and that radio broadcasters will need to understand the relationship between sound and vision. We receive sound and then make pictures in the mind but to make sense of sound we need codes to know what it is and make sense of it. 
Chapter five will critically examine the issues of commercial success in radio and where pictures could help improve the radio experience as there are some things that radio is restricted to as a sound only medium. This will be
considered to see whether radio can be improved with graphics and pictures. 
Chapter six will provide a background to the equipment available for the reception of digital radio and the
receivers needed for picture radio. In addition the type of programmes that could be enhanced, as other media has, by the use of pictures and illustrations will be considered.
Also there will be a critical discussion on the use of picture radio worldwide and the place of picture radio in international radio broadcasting.

bibo:shortTitle: A redesign of the Beneteau 40.7 for optimised racing performance.
bibo:abstract:
The Beneteau 40.7 launched in 1998 and built by Beneteau France, is a one-design cruiser racer. Racing fleets of 40.7's are very predominant in Spain, France, United Kingdom and Australia. These boats have been campaigned within large handicap events and appear to be very at home
under race conditions, in part due to there excellent rating under the IRC and IMS rules, and also due to their exciting sailing characteristics. They are also equally at home cruising long distances at speed and in relative comfort.
The true racing pedigree of this yacht is held back by the dual-purpose nature of the boat. The boat is a light displacement boat that is built using very basic specifications, and materials. The essence of this boat is two fold – cruising and racing, but a fact of life is that the racing pedigree of the hull form is held back by the sheer nature that the boat has to be able to be cruised in
comfort and safety. It is for this reason that the idea of cruiser / racer is going to be changed to out and out racer. To do this the same hull form will be used to produce a high specification race boat that can compete with the likes of Farr 40’s, Mumm 36’s and other well-known race boats in this category.

bibo:shortTitle: The development of resource management and leadership behavioural markers for the Merchant Navy.
bibo:abstract:
Resource Management principles, first established in the aviation industry, have been adapted and adopted for the Merchant Navy  and other safety critical areas  where the importance of the blend of effective technical and non-technical skills is recognised.  

The proposed revisions to the STCW Code include requirements for deck and engineering officers to show competence in the non-technical skills of Resource Management.  
These proposed Resource Management competencies do not align fully with other industries’ established criteria.  The many unique aspects of the international maritime industry make the wholesale adoption of established criteria from another industry inappropriate. 

This research sets out to identify whether the broad competence criteria described in the STCW revisions would be consistently interpreted by a range of industry stakeholders, in the context of the behaviours that they would expect to see, hear or experience in demonstrating compliance with, and evidencing competence in, the criteria.

The paper will report on areas where respondents clearly identified effective and ineffective behavioural markers.  Where such evidence was not forthcoming or requires amplification, the authors will propose effective and ineffective markers.  It is anticipated that continuing research will validate the effectiveness and utility of the behavioural markers.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into the mode of failure secondary bonding.
bibo:abstract: One of the major problems of failure in composite construction is through problems with secondary bonding. Preparation methods to achieve ideal conditions for secondary bonding are diverse and disputed. Although many processes have been tested and quantified by the aviation industry, procedures in the marine composite industry remain unregulated and varied. The purpose of this paper is to define a relative level of bonding integrity through testing a variation in surface preparation of composites. The effect of incorrect mix ratios in adhesive preparation is also investigated. A literature review of relevant information regarding secondary bonding techniques and related issues is made. Conclusions from the tests made and current information available is used to propose a relative superior method for preparation and application of secondary bonds in composites.

bibo:shortTitle: Proposing a Framework for Blended and Flexible Course Design
bibo:abstract: This paper proposes a Framework for Blended and Flexible Curriculum Delivery. Following a brief introduction about how this project came together, a literature review is undertaken where various terms related with learning and teaching through technology are explained and distinguished. The proposed Blended Learning Framework is explained, discussed, analyzed and mapped to educational practices and their underpinning learning theories. The paper is then summarized and concluded.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into tourist expectations and space tourism
Preliminary design of a 14m-15m Blue Water Cruiser.
bibo:abstract: In September 2002, three random people enquired at the Ancasta Lymington Used Boat Show about purchasing a steel blue water cruiser, around 40ft-50ft, that would easily accommodate two to three people at any one time, but with the additional accommodation for up to six, in case of visitors aboard the vessel for a leg of the journey etc. This thought was discussed in particular with one customer, and ideas as to what type of vessel was to be developed. This idea was then taken and used as one of three initial ideas and picked out for further development. Three weeks into the project, a final design proposal was submitted to the assigned tutors. Once feedback had been received from this, a preliminary design was created. The basis of this was to be very simple, but to outline all ideas that were to form the base of the hull design. This included a preliminary sail area, hull lines plan, general arrangement, initial structures and a deck plan. This lead to a formal presentation of all ideas in February 2003 to two lecturers. Feedback was given at the end of the each presentation, enabling more ideas to be considered and more areas of design to be attempted. These comments in mind, the last design leg was to complete all structural calculations, finalise a sail area, general arrangement, deck plan, promotional drawings, structural design and to discuss the development of the design.

bibo:shortTitle: 14m cruising sailing catamaran.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this final year dissertation was to improve and expand on many studied areas that have been covered over the past three years. The aim of this project is to investigate and understand the elements involved in the design of a sailing cruising catamaran.
Catamarans provide a different idea of sailing and the design has to satisfy the client’s requirements: good accommodation with comfortable exterior and in particular
interior spaces, performance, shallow draft which provides access to difficult places, ease of handling and comfort underway, stability with minimal heeling and minimal
rolling downwind and safety to survive from severe weather.
The design of this type of boat presents many particulars which have to be considered with caution. The main objective is to get a better understanding of all associated problems involved in the design of catamaran both from the structural point of view and from the hydrodynamic point of view.
Sailing catamaran are growing up in the actual market. The bad reputation as a craft easy to capsize is disappearing and the sailing cruising market is allowing an increasing in space. Multihulls show a pleasant idea of sailing for leisure and commercial purposes.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 17m luxury sportfishing vessel.
bibo:abstract: The concept of this project is to design a sport-fishing/dive motor yacht. As it was said in an earlier project proposal, the aim is to complete a preliminary design for a motor yacht, between 15 – 20m in length. It will include weight estimates, interior arrangements, scantling dimensions, power estimates, stability calculations and fuel capacity and range calculations. At the end, an evaluation of the whole project will be carried out and improvements that could be made to the project will be pointed out. A breakdown of time spent on each area will also be carried out.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 40ft cruiser-racer.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this project was to realize the full design of a cruiser-racer with the sailing performance as priority. The length of this yacht was not fixed at the start of the study; it was decided to do a rapid marketing study in order to know which range of size is actually the most popular and the most benefic to build.
Moreover, it was chosen to design a yacht suitable for a serial production, which has imposed some restrictions on the overall design as the comfort, cost, production feasibility, etc. The final yacht was thought in order to group advantages of the competition with a minimum of their disadvantages to please clients.
It will be detailed on this report all the design process, from the parametric study to the velocity prediction in passing by all the loops realized to correct the design all along the project. Problems encounter will be equally presented with their answers chosen to solve them.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of 45ft IRM monohull racing yacht.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project is to produce a preliminary design for a custom built racing monohull yacht which complies with the IRM section (IRM rule) of the IR2000 time on time measurement and rating system for monohull yachts (IR2000 system) which is administered by the Royal Ocean Racing Club (RORC) and the L’Union National pour la Course au Large (UNCL). The objective of the project is for the design to have theoretical performance, which would enable it to win a wide range of races that are run using the IR2000 system. The theoretical performance standard that the design is to meet will be decided as the project process and is dependant on benchmark information that can be obtained and that is of a sufficient standard deemed by the designer. The only specifications set for the design is for it to have a rated length (L) as defined in the IRM rule of 45ft or 13.715m and for the design to full comply with the IRM rule so it would be able to obtain a IRM certificate and rating value. All other dimension and specification will be decided as the project process and will be set so as to achieve the stated objective.

bibo:shortTitle: Foilborn formula 18.
bibo:abstract: The aim of the design in this report is to design a day sailing catamaran which can be supported on foils. The rules follow the Formula 18 class.

bibo:shortTitle: Oceanographic primary researches sailing catamarans.
bibo:abstract:
The purpose of this final year project is to design a sailing vessel which is able to ride seas around the world, except austral seas. The main concept is to imagine an environmentally friendly powered boat first by reducing the entreaty of the generator by using solar cells ,photovoltaic panels and horizontal or vertical wind turbines. The coupling of both systems,(sun and wind) , will produce enough energy for the comfort of life. This concept boat leads directly to a coastal laboratory for primary research sailing boat. The vessel should have comfortable accommodations for 2 skippers and 4 scientists ( accounting that the scientists onboard are already experimented sailing people ).
The vessel will include glass panels under the hull working with structural and moving doors once arrived in shallow water. The role envisaged of the vessel should include research works at sea such as archeology and oceanography in shallow water.(Marine wild life logging, photography, filming, primary analysis and scuba-diving activity). The vessel will also be used as a form of transport for a light amount of samples so the vessel would include a crane to carry objects out of water, and as a base for land research expeditions into areas which are difficult to access and which needs relatively small vessel draught to be investigated. The role of adventure charter needs also to be fulfilled

bibo:shortTitle: Self build trimaran.
bibo:abstract:
The Self build trimaran project was undertaken for several reasons. It all started from a design contest organized by the Norway Multihull Association in May 2002 which goal was to promote a fast and exiting cruiser racer multihull with a limited cost of construction. This contest appears to enlighten an area of the pleasure boat market in which there is a lack of choice in existing designs but which is increasingly taking the attention of the public.
The philosophy of the project was there and the area of research could then be set up. The first step was an investigation on sailing cruiser racer multihulls. The water plan of Southampton Water and its multihull series gave some light on the way trimarans are sailing and which are the successful designs. The conclusions so far were that such kind of boats should be more famous because they propose a really fun alternative to club series and short cruising.
The second step was to investigate on design considerations specific to multihulls through literature and designers advices. The study covered the whole modern history of sailing on several hulls, from the early ‘racing’ proa to the latest high tech machines which represent a very dynamic field for experimentation.
The next step was to investigate on construction methods and materials to use to bring the price down. With no much compromise on the performance and looking of the final product, the way forward was to propose a self build boat using modern methods of construction.
Once these main objectives were identified, the design spiral could be primed.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a luxury yacht for racing and charter.
bibo:abstract:
The modern yacht has advanced in construction techniques, using exotic fibres and resins to produce highly competitive boats. This has increased the overall cost of construction and maintenance, due to this increase these yachts can no longer survive as pure race boats, with sponsorship and have to earn money by providing a service, in the expanding market of corporate entertainment and luxury cruising. To do this requires the yacht to operate in a diverse set of conditions, whilst being able to maintain its style and elegance. For the architect this can prove an intriguing challenge to balance the elegance and style required of a luxury yacht and the harsh essentials of a race boat, it has been tackled by only a few and has produced a selection of hybrid yachts.
The aims and objectives of this dissertation are to provide a preliminary design for a 24m dual purpose yacht that is stylish and competitive, as this is essential to its commercial viability. It should be able to race under the International Measurement System (IMS) ‘Maxi’ and IR Calculated (IRC) class, the preliminary structural design will need to comply with Lloyds Special Service Craft (SSC) or American Bureau of Shipping (ABS) guide for building and classing Offshore Racing Yachts.
To enable the yacht to operate in the charter market it will need to meet the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA), code of practice for sailing vessels up to 24 metres load line length.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 24m blue water cruising yacht.
bibo:abstract: There is a growing trend among cruising yacht owners to commission larger and larger boats, part of this is vanity, the use of a yacht to display ones financial standing, but there is a increasing number of yacht persons who have discovered a lifestyle away from the high paced hustle of urban life. The increasing number of long term or live aboard cruisers that spend their time sailing between islands in subtropical climates have their own demands on a yacht. For them increased size means more comfortable surroundings and greater range but this is not without its costs, in terms of increased mooring fees and higher maintenance bills. The aim is to design a yacht for these people, although clearly placed in the top end of the market at 24m, this yacht will be as at home moored in Mote Carlo, as it will be cruising in the Pacific Ocean. The accommodation is luxurious, and due to its layout, the yacht can be sailed by a small group of cruising friends or by a professional crew for the owner. Equipped with an easy to handle moderate performance rig that can be completely controlled from the helm position this yacht also offers safety to her crew and guests.

bibo:shortTitle: The London 2012 Olympics and its economic impact
Workshop service as a significant contribution to the value chain of a large scale car manufacturer
Microfinance and sustainable development in West Bengal
Customer's perception on marketing promotional mix of Red Bull: an international perspective on how this is influenced by environmental factors
Design of ultra light displacement wooden boat.
bibo:abstract:
The conception of a cruising yacht might be seen as a straight forward project, but the actual project is to design a boat with large horizon easy to handle with restricted crew as well as being capable of entering in a racing programme such as the 40 open class.
The design of this modern boat is to be done in the traditional way with specific regard to the lifting keel
The aim of this design is to regroup all the theory which I have learnt during three years and to put them all into practice to obtain a sailing vessel able to satisfy a river or an ocean voyage by a sensitive helmsman. The American Bureau of Shipping & the Maritime Coastguard Agency rules have been followed to obtain a safe yacht.

bibo:shortTitle: 50ft cruiser-racer catamaran.
bibo:abstract:
Up to the 80’s, the world of catamarans has been evolving in a parallel to the one of monohulls. During that period, racing or tropical chartering were mainly their domains and the corresponding design approach almost automatically leaded to either non-aesthetic heavy crafts or pure racing machines. Their entrance and full acceptance as pure owner’s boat in the European public field is only recent. This change in mind is probably due to the evolution of their design aspect, nowadays more inspired by the free spirit expression of wild racing large multihulls (The Race around the world event) along with the willing of rather fortunate owners to afford comfortable craft, nonetheless capable of achieving more than respectable average speeds. In this respect, a few races were borne (mainly being organised in the tropical areas of the globe), gathering more and more owners each year, mainly interested by conjugating the pleasure of fast sailing and friendly port of calls.
As new exotic materials really started to appear on the commercial field (90’s) as a consequence of racing yachts development and of their application process being correctly controlled by a few boatyards, commercial catamarans could start to beneficiate from quality (relatively) lightweight building and so become more performative without losing their ability to offer comfort onboard.
As this evolution of the building processes is still going on, and the demand for this type of craft is still increasing, it appears interesting to try investigating this path of naval architecture and try to apply the theoretical skills learnt during these three years on a real complete personal design.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of an Open 35ft for the Istar.
bibo:abstract: In the following pages, the preliminary design of a racing 35’ yacht specifically designed to achieve maximum performance in the Ostar race has been developed, with the objective to have a clear overview for the reader of all the aspect involved in a design process of this kind. Consideration on the design of the hull, appendages and rig has been done, and early in the reading it can be understand that improvements in performance can be only achieved by a deep study on one particular aspect of the design, for example improving the rig efficiency. This report needs therefore to be approached as a research of possible improvements where some proposition is done.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of an IRM 52.
bibo:abstract: The preliminary design of an IRM 52.

bibo:shortTitle: IMS design case study.
bibo:abstract: This report wants to be a general introduction to the IMS world, with its rules and its prediction. After a brief introduction through the main changes of the design of racing yachts been rated over the years, a careful analysis of the IMS VPP Algorithms will be carried out to find out the hidden factors that make a IMS design faster on the paper as well as on the water. The focus will then move onto different aspects of the design, but always cross checking the choices made with prediction of the VPP. Two hulls will be analysed and compared to be then rated under the IMS rules to find the optimum hull shape.

bibo:shortTitle: A preliminary hydrofoil borne Orma 60 trimaran design, including a velocity prediction method.
bibo:abstract:
Having an interest for high speed sailing crafts, and a curiosity of hydrofoils, it was decided to combine the interests and perform an investigation of the feasibility of a hydrofoil borne ORMA 60 Trimaran.
The aim of this project has been to design a Hydrofoil Borne ORMA 60 Trimaran and to investigate the feasibility, advantages and disadvantages of a fully hydrofoil borne ORMA 60 Trimaran in comparison with the more common hydrofoil “supported” ORMA 60 Trimarans.
The design process has focused on the construction of a velocity prediction program. By investigating the hydrodynamic behaviour of the hydrofoil borne boat, it has been possible to construct a hydrodynamic model. A simpler aerodynamic model has been constructed and, by applying a solver function in Excel, the force and moment equilibrium of the system was found, and a polar plot was produced from the results.
Towing tank testing has been performed with the aim of validating the designed hydrofoil configuration and the methods used in the construction of the velocity prediction program. It was found that the foil configuration was working as intended, and that the methods applied in the velocity prediction was slightly underestimating the drag of the hydrofoil borne boat.
It was also found that a flow separation occurred on the hydrofoils during the tank testing, and an investigation of cavitation and ventilation inception has therefore been carried out. It was found that the problem with cavitation and ventilation does not scale up, and that ventilation will occur at higher Froude Numbers on the full size boat than it was the case with the model.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 12m one-off cruiser/racer yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The final year project offers the opportunity to the student to get an overview on the Yacht Designer’s job using the different methodologies learnt during the course and to investigate more deeply some technical aspects.
The concept of a 40’ cruiser/racer is proven and is based on an existing market. Many aspects such as going fast and far in good living conditions, a limited cost in relation to the multiple programme offered (cruising and / or racing) are really attractive. Such a project is quite classical but to a student point of view it allows to initiate the project on a sound basis and therefore to perform properly its technical side.
The general design work was carried out using the design spiral concept by refining the different stages in an iterative process. A comparative method was used to determine in a quantitative way some particular aspects of this design spiral such as hull shape, yacht structure and keel and rig design.
Thus the hull design made use of the Delft series together with a VPP program and basic Naval Architecture calculations to determine the optimal hull shape with regards to the design targets. Likewise the VPP program allowed to compare three different rig types together with two sort of keel types. The different solutions in terms of material and type of structure were principally compared on a weight basis since the CR 40
The work presented in this project is not exhaustive but a sufficient range of aspects was treated to offer a good overview on the yacht design.

bibo:shortTitle: The initial design on an America's Cup class yacht.
bibo:abstract:
This report outlines the initial design of an America’s Cup Class yacht. After investigation of the ACC rule, several options allowable were identified for consideration. These were then analysed using VPP software and compared objectively with performance in mind. A chosen design configuration, progressed to a suitable stage to perform initial structural calculations, is presented.
Initial structural design calculations, made on the basis of classification society rules, were carried out. Initial scantlings resulting from this analysis were then checked against primary loading criterion and appropriate alterations were made.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design for a 27m luxury power catamaran.
bibo:abstract:
The design featured in this report is for a 27m luxury power catamaran. The vessel is to operate primarily in the Mediterranean region, but has the desired capability to cross the Atlantic to reach the Caribbean islands. The vessel performance requirements were quite specific in the design brief. The vessel was required to achieve a maximum speed of thirty knots, with the ability to maintain an ocean passage cruising speed of no less than ten knots. To achieve these performance targets, twin 651KW Caterpillar marine diesel engines have been installed. The required engine power being determined by utilising systematic series resistance and powering prediction methods for semi displacement catamaran hull forms.
The use of the vessel has been designed to be multi faceted. Thus having the ability to accommodate the owner and their guests in lavish surroundings, whilst maintaining the ability for the vessel to act as a business platform. With the possibility of the vessel carrying more than twelve passengers, the vessel has been designed to comply with MCA codes of practice for large commercial sailing and power vessels. Further more the vessels structural configuration has been designed to comply with the Lloyd’s Register Special Service Craft Regulations.

bibo:shortTitle: Design proposal for a 24m passenger pleasure craft for the Floating Harbour in Bristol.
bibo:abstract: The following report outlines the process undertaken toward completion of a proposal for a 24 m passenger vessel for the Floating Harbour in Bristol. It describes the methods used for gathering relevant information and discusses requirements before presenting a proposal. Contained within the report are a draft stability book, detailed resistance and powering calculations and a section on the structural arrangement. Drawings are included at the end.

bibo:shortTitle: The economic motive and impact of foreign direct investment (FDI) in United Arab Emirates (UAE): the foreign investors perspective
Preliminary design of a luxury cruising high speed catamaran.
bibo:abstract: Small sporty catamaran motor boats start to become increasingly popular in Europe and consequently this lead for the author to extend the research to bigger size boat in order to produce a luxury catamaran motor yacht, surpassing in space accommodation, comfort, stability and speed the 10 feet bigger monohulls. The boat should have been comfortable, spacious for six people to live onboard during short cruises, well motorized to sail a top speed of 45+ knots and be also economic to have a sailing range of over 700 miles. All other aspects have been let to the feeling of the author.

bibo:shortTitle: Clusters and competitive advantage in the United Arab Emirates: an exploratory case study of financial services
The effects of store cards
Property business in Cyprus run by families

Mergers and acquisitions in Banco Santander and how they
help banks grow and become successful.
A study into the seriousness of "osmosis" in FRP construction.
bibo:abstract:
The project's aim was to study the seriousness of "osmosis" in FRP construction. The study was carried out by extensive research into manufacturing processes and materials and contemporary views on the subject of osmosis. It was found that the process of "osmosis" does not occur within FRP. The process that is causing damage is the process of "Hydrolysis" reacting between the water and the acids and glycols in the resin. This process caused the resin to break down and form Phthalic acid crystals, which further degrade the laminate.
The current repair methods, favoured by many marine repair companies, were found to be insufficient in dealing with the products of the "hydrolysis" process, and were in effect sealing the acidic crystals inside the laminate with the possibility of further damage going undetected. This problem could be avoided by the use of high temperature vacuum treatments to remove the products of "hydrolysis" before coating the hull.
In the case study vessel, the "CONTESSA 32", it was found that by changing from an isophthalic gelcoat to an isophthalic neopentyl glycol gelcoat, the laminate would posses increased resistance to water ingress at a minimal cost. This would increase both the appeal of the product and the sales value.

bibo:shortTitle: Large composite (super) structures on yachts.
bibo:abstract:
This report will solely concentrate on the Dutch yacht manufacturing industry. The 'superyacht' industry has undergone a significant growth, with Holland playing a key roll; there is an increasing demand for installation and construction of lightweight composite components. This is caused by the urge for higher performance of these yachts. For motoryachts these components can be individual moving parts like large doors, hatches, the superstructure or even the entire hull. Even on large sailing yachts this weight reduction can have a significant effect when its desk houses, deck or entire hull are constructed from composite materials.
To prove that composite materials are able to perform just as well or even better a comparison against traditional materials is demonstrated. The advantages adn disadvantages of both materials, with regard to their properties are being discussed to provide a clear view of the capabilities of composite materials.

bibo:shortTitle: Does the RYA need to introduce engine guidelines for safety boats.
bibo:abstract:
The watersports industry is one of the biggest growing sectors in an already massive leisure market. Because of the industry growing at the rate it has been there have been some areas which have not been given the full attention they should. One of these is the area that this report is going to be looking at.
‘Guidelines of engine suitability for safety boats’ There is a real lack of knowledge within in the structure of RYA (Royal Yachting Association) recognised establishments (such as sailing clubs/centres) on what is the right engine size for the conditions and usage that they give there safety boats.
The main reason for this report coming to light at all was because of a conversation had with a member of the RYA... 
Data has been collected through questionnaire and interview on what the industry is using for safety boats and what type of engines they have. This has been pulled together and analysed to produce the second part of the report.
This included carrying out an experiment to help determine to actual power required to tow certain dinghies. Also to produce guidelines on what type of engine suits the relevant types of usage that centres/sailing clubs might require.

bibo:shortTitle: Design conversion of a 1951 surveying vessel into a luxury explorer yacht suitable for charter.
bibo:abstract:
There is a growing awareness of the potential benefits of acquiring and converting vessels into private yachts. In the current market place, there are a remarkable number of commercial vessels currently available for sale at a very competitive price.
These vessels have become available for a wide variety of reasons which include changes in the market need, changes in crewing philosophy, or as part of planned replacement policy. Where some of them are unattractive in appearance, in need of major restorative repair or uneconomical to continue to operate – thus have become available to be scrapped. While there are always a significant number of existing yachts offered for sale, the appearance, standard of construction and the interior may not meet the desires of an owner. A conversion becomes only beneficial to the owner if the chosen vessel can be produced in a time and cost saving package compared to a new build.
For this purpose, “ANTARES” shown below, was a 1951 Dutch pilot and surveying vessel, which has been chosen to be used as a “donor” vessel for the conversion to an Explorer Yacht. This project identifies the main areas of concern for the conversion and uses the Maritime and Coastguard Agency code of practice for the safety of large commercial sailing & motor vessels to analyse and assess the situation.
Plate 1 showing “ANTARES” in her present appearance
Problems associated with stability, fire protection and cost estimation of such are discussed and solutions to the problems offered. An approach of project management based on research and the use of charts to produce a precedence diagram that shows the sequence of the conversion process, have also been produced. Furthermore, a final 3-D model has been created to show how the vessel could look like based on the conversion work required (See Appendix XIX, p. 90-91).
As a major design feature, which is a build in hangar that houses a helicopter, the need to compliance to the Safety of Life at Sea for the fire protection and system becomes a major issue which could affect the total cost of the vessel. The cost of conversion has been derived from a collection of 37 Explorer yachts that are represented in the form of a linear equation from a graph.
The converted vessel at the end shows all features an Explorer Yacht can offer and combines “vintage” with a modern touch. The result of the estimated cost and the time scale may show an ideal vessel waiting to be converted.

bibo:shortTitle: A study into the conversion of a 'Challenge 67' racing yacht into a world cruising yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The purpose of the study is to examine a Challenge 67 racing yacht and assess its suitability for conversion into a world cruising yacht.
The Challenge Business currently owns a number of ex race yachts which have subsequently been used for adventure sailing and corporate entertaining. The 67 fleet, now twelve years old, has been superseded by a fleet of 72’ yachts. Several yachts have been sold to various organisations as training vessels. This study examines an alternative use.
The definition of a world cruising yacht has been examined, through the use of a parametric study. Although this provided some indication of what is required it was found to be rather ambiguous.
In an attempt to define a purpose to which the converted yacht could be specified, a passage plan for an extended cruise has been created. Some conclusions with regard to systems and equipment levels have been used to augment the information from the parametric study.
Based on the information gathered, a specification has been created using manufacturers literature, drawings and information supplied by Challenge Business. Issues such as the addition of new systems, a new accommodation layout, vessel performance and behaviour, stability and the addition of watertight bulkheads have been considered and evaluated with the help of various software packages and guidance from the MCA code book for small commercial sailing vessels.
To carry out a conversion project as described has significant implications in terms of cost and the time required. These issues have been examined and an estimate of both has been made in conjunction with a proposal for the sequence in which it should be carried out. The basis for the estimate is information supplied by equipment manufacturers and input from industry specialists.
The study concludes that a conversion as proposed is viable. Total converted vessel cost is not prohibitive providing the specification exactly fulfils the owners requirements. However there is unlikely to be significant profit in the conversion itself if the yacht is to remain saleable. The converted vessel would have a ‘general’ specification not tailored to an owner and considerable capital would be tied up for the duration of the project. For these reasons it is considered ideal for Challenge to sell the yachts as vessels which are suitable for conversion but not to undertake the conversion themselves.

bibo:shortTitle: Conversion of HMS Warrior to a fully functioning passenger ship, with an in depth cost evaluation of the re-fit process on a 20 year plan.
bibo:abstract:
As the title describes, this project is aimed to determine the feasibility of converting HMS Warrior from its current state, berthed in Portsmouth harbour as a floating museum, into a fully functioning cruise ship. In order for this to be achieved, Warrior will have to undergo many changes.
The first question which needs to be answered is. What will HMS Warrior be transformed into? And the second is. How will this be achieved? This second question forms the majority of this project.
There are many options as to how Warrior could be changed. This ranges from: Changing her into a luxury cruise ship to rival the Star Clipper range of ships; to keeping her aesthetically original in design and turning her into an historical tall ship; or even a combination of the two.

bibo:shortTitle: The re-design of an existing Farr 52 hull into a performance cruiser/racer.
bibo:abstract:
Design developed by Farr International Inc. The success of this boat over the last four years is in part due to her being competitive under IMS, IRC and IRM rating rules, but also a credit to her quick and exciting sailing characteristics.
The Farr 52 OD is a moderate-to-light displacement race boat, built from pre-preg carbon and epoxy, vacuum bagged and heat cured. Features include a runnerless rig built by Hall spars, non-overlapping headsails by North Sails and twin grinding pedestals by Lewmar. The essence of this boat is performance, but a fact of life is that such performance is soon out-done on the racecourse. It is on this poignant point that I would like to investigate the viability of creating a successful and practical conversion for the Farr 52 from a high-performance and specialist race boat to a cruiser-racer, with the scope for competing in offshore cruising regattas.
“There is a wonderful fascination about yacht designing because of the opportunity generally afforded the designer for the experiment toward improvement of type.” (Skene. Ref .1).
My vision of the re-designed cruiser-racer is of a sleek and contemporary styled yacht that maintains an exhilarating performance. It is intended that the yacht’s handling is simplified to ensure that life aboard is comfortable and relaxing for a crew of five/ six. Although this vessel will not be a world cruiser by nature, it is intended that long ocean passages will be a joy and not a chore.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into impact testing of epoxy resins and the reliability of its results.
bibo:abstract:
Composite structures are used in a variety of applications be it aircraft, marine, automobiles and protective clothing to name but a few. Testing these structures to obtain their mechanical properties is essential in optimizing and characterising their characteristics.
This project concentrates on the composite materials being used within the marine industry being carbon, Kevlar®, and epoxy resin lay-up. The main body of the report compares the impact properties of the new M1002 laminating resin developed by Wessex Resins and Adhesives in comparison with their old ProSet 145 resin. It will investigate the process of impact testing, the various test methods and the standards involved. With the testing of the two resin systems the study will also set out to determine whether or not the samples are “notch sensitive” and if the standards affect the final results given. But even with standards written by societies such as ISO and ASTM how reliable are these test results? That is the question that this paper is going to investigate and try to answer.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into copper epoxy antifouling and galvanic corrosion.
bibo:abstract:
This project examines the information and knowledge available regarding copper epoxy antifouling and its effect on galvanic corrosion. There are so many opposing views; it was felt that some research into the subject was warranted especially on wooden vessels. Starting with the history of copper as an antifouling agent, moving through various types of cladding and production using copper nickel, and finally to the state of the art, copper epoxy antifouling. Research into the knowledge in the public domain was carried out through the medium of a questionnaire. Some short term experiments were executed using samples of Copperguard a copper epoxy antifouling system. These experiments looked at the reliability, flexibility, and the level of galvanic corrosion on timber impaled with different metals, and other substances clad with Copperguard and immersed in sea water. It would appear from these short term samples that Copperguard may in fact help to prevent galvanic corrosion. Long term tests need to be performed to provide evidence over five, ten and twenty years before an absolute conclusion may be drawn.
There is a cost comparison between traditional antifouling and Copperguard over a ten year period.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a purpose built dive R.I.B.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this project is to design a rigid inflatable boat that will meet the specific requirements for use with divers.
This project will initially look at current similar designs both within the diving industry and within the entire rigid inflatable boat market, the collected data will be compiled to create a parametric study of suitable similar designs. In order to compare the designs current existing ratios may have to be tailored to meet the characteristics of a RIB. Using this along with further research the project will fully assess the exact requirements of the intended design including the principal dimensions.
Once all the required data has been collected a suitable design will be drawn up to satisfy the needs of divers and to comply with the current regulations.

bibo:shortTitle: Is it viable to harmonise all worldwide recreational craft manufacturing regulations into one internationally recognised standard?
bibo:abstract: A detailed analysis of all the worldwide rules and regulations for the building of recreational craft is beyond the scope of this project, it is therefore proposed to look at the main standards present in the areas of the EU and USA to give an overview of the subject. An in-depth investigation of one aspect of construction will be used to highlight the problems of compliance and the differences between the varying regulations. This particular stage will focus on ‘diesel fuel systems’ and their corresponding regulations. Careful studying of these regulations should reveal the differences and possible reasons why these differences exist. Schematic drawings will be produced to illustrate the regulatory differences that currently exist between countries. This investigation should lead to an informed conclusion as to whether a harmonised international standard is desirable or achievable.

bibo:shortTitle: A theoretical investigation of management disciplines and philosophies applied to yacht manufacturing companies.
bibo:abstract:
This project deals with the issues of a management team in a yacht manufacturing company. The yachting industry in itself is a cottage industry, for some people it builds what is essential but for most is a luxury item. In recent decades, big companies and small companies alike have gone bankrupt, some with lack of work planned and some with full order books in hand. This can be a disaster for the communities that are affected by the job losses and loss of income to the community. This could have been caused by ineffective management practices, lack of morale, product life cycle, and most probably a mix of all of these. I’m going to investigate management practices and theories, and see whether they would have an impact on the companies to make them more efficient, friendly, and successful and ensure their long term life.
Two theoretical model companies were constructed, based on stereotypical yacht manufacturing companies and they are used to base the findings on. I picked ten areas of research to look into that are related to management, engineering principles, philosophies and team ethos. I have them applied these on to the model companies and thought about how they would work retrospectively on them. Some of them are very applicable to standard engineering management teams and some to smaller management systems.
The two companies both benefited from the thought and change made from the philosophies proposed, my first smaller model company theoretically could make huge changes to the way it works, a lot of it background work of the management side that would make it work more efficient, improving communication, more job planning, and a better work environment for the managers and staff. The second company I found is more executively based management already and benefits from some review and thought, and can also improve through quality accreditations and improved communication. It does however have to extremely aware of the product life cycles of the products it is building, and be flexible to meet their demands. The customer or client has to be considered and thought what he wants, but not at the expense of the downfall of the business.
This project theoretically designs the two model companies as they could improve as best it can in theoretical terms. In real life there would be other problems, and other issues may come along, what I have inbuilt into both designs is input to management levels from staff and improved communication, which is the only way these problems come into the open instead of coming out at the end of a project when it is too late. The manager of any company shouldn’t be someone who is unapproachable by his staff, and his floor managers should know what is going on and any problems, potential or current, with the staff in the company.

bibo:shortTitle: Investigating the attitudes held by Southampton Solent University undergraduates towards the consumption of British veal

Development and how HRD strategies have been
impacted by the recession 2007-2010

Creativity measurement analysis
Climate change- effects on the European and German economy
Preliminary design for a Max Z86 racer.
bibo:abstract:
This project outlines the preliminary design of a MaxZ86 racer. According to the class rule an investigation was carried out to determine the dimensions of the sled. Several tools such as the VPP were used to assess the perfomances of this boats able to reach awful speeds. A configuration was chosen according to the previous results.
An investigation of the structural issues involved by the appendages configuration was carried out.
A preliminary scantling arrangement was carried out according to the American Bureau of Shipping. This structural arrangement was checked and corrected assuming a primary loading case due to wave and rig tension.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of an IMS 50' racer.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this project is to design a 50´IMS Racer.
The boat should be comfortably sailed by a crew of around 13 persons and should be optimised for the IMS Rule, she should be classified in the Category A of the ISO standards and she will meet all the requirements specified in the IMS regulations.

bibo:shortTitle: The Preliminary Design of a Volvo Open 70’.
bibo:abstract:
I have followed the last Volvo Ocean Race during the first year of my study; I had a great interest to discover the rule that governed that great example of yacht design but I was only starting to get my first ideas on yacht design.
With the oncoming of the new rule I have had a great opportunity to bring forward this design study and produce the preliminary design of a Volvo Open 70’.

bibo:shortTitle: 60' aluminium cruiser.
bibo:abstract: The aim of the following design is to produce a pleasant and secure sailing vessel as well for short month travels (e.g. the tour of the Mediterranean Sea) as for long Around the World trips. This yacht has for particularity to be able to reach any place, even in shallow waters like harbors or rivers despite her large size.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 105ft, 50 knot custom motor yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this project was to produce the overall preliminary design of a 105 foot, 50 knot custom motor yacht. The reason for choosing this topic was to grasp the first and probably last chance to work on TRIPPPLE COURTNEY, a boat where every aspect would be designed according to the author’s ideas, wishes and preferences. In this context, an important aspect of the project is reflected in the design philosophy:
“TRIPPPLE COURTNEY shall be purposefully designed as high performance powerboat. It shall be able to offer thrills and excitement together with a high level of comfort both under way and at anchor. These qualities shall not express themselves in-, or be compromised by luxury.”
During the course of the project, most areas relevant for a preliminary design have been covered. These included parametric study, weights and centres estimates using different techniques, resistance and powering estimates using different techniques, planing hull form design, planing hull detail design, structural design in aluminium and FRP, propulsion system design, intact and damaged stability analysis, classification society compliance, product research, styling, design of interior layout and design optimisation. Whilst all of these aspects have been addressed, they were only taken to a preliminary design stage. Cost was not considered in any part of the project.
Savitsky planing theory, the DNV rules for structural design, MCA regulations for stability, Maxsurf®, Hydromax®, Hull Speed®, Wolfson powering prediction software, Rhinoceros®, AutoCAD®, the Microsoft® packages, Adobe Paint Shop Pro® and the knowledge and theory accumulated during the BEng “Yacht and Powercraft Design” degree were the most important tools used in the process.
After two complete loops around the design spiral plus additional work in the areas of hull form design, powering and general arrangement, the most important design decisions had been made and a sensible result had been achieved. Only the fuel capacity and maximum range remained a problem. Neglecting this issue, the design had converged sufficiently to be able to say it could be taken to the detailed design stage.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 36 foot fast cruising catamaran in hard chine plywood construction.
bibo:abstract: The object of this project was to develop a preliminary design of a small cruising catamaran for self builders - the ‘Ply-Cat 36’. The emphasis of the project is set on the terms self building and long term cruising.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a fast and economic sailing yacht.
bibo:abstract:
This report presents the design of a fast cruising yacht with a study on shallow draft appendages.
In part A, after the design brief analysis, different kind of shallow draft appendages are described, a sensible length for the boat is determined, and a parametric study is done, as well as a preliminary weight estimate. After the preliminary design, different points are developed:
First of all, the hull design, part B, where the choice of a hard chine hull, the specificity of this kind of hull, and the assessment of it performances are explained.
In part C, the structural design is developed. The ABS has been used. This part contends a discussion on wood properties, and the use and advantages of plywood to easily build a fast cheap sailing yacht.
Finally, in part D, appendage design is developed. A sensible choice has to be made between a twin keel and a lifting single keel, in an attempt to design a shallow draft
version. First of the problem is analysed, some assumption are made on the limits of the theory used to determine the limits of both configurations.

bibo:shortTitle: A preliminary design for a 53'catamaran suitable for disabled sailing.
bibo:abstract: A preliminary design for a 53'catamaran suitable for disabled sailing.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of the IRM 45 "Momette".
bibo:abstract: This project aims to design a one off-design 45-footer monohull sailing yacht, made to compete in IRM events.

bibo:shortTitle: Volvo Open 70 with investigation into hull and appendages design.
bibo:abstract: The main aim of the project is to investigate the hull and appendages design on a Volvo Open 70. These boats are designed to a new rule, and therefore much work is currently being done on these boats.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 50 feet one-off day-boat.
bibo:abstract: The aims and objectives of this dissertation are to realise a preliminary design of a leisure sailing day-boat. At the beginning of the study, the different overall length of the boat had not yet been decided. A quick study of the market and research into the best compromise between length, space and luxury was carried out. It was decided that an approximately 50 foot long yacht is the best compromise and unusual for a day boat.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 24 meter sailing yacht.
bibo:abstract: In this project a preliminary design of a 24 meter sailing yacht is undertaken. The yacht is going to be used for charter in unrestricted area. The intention is to cover most aspects that are of major importance of the preliminary design, however the main focus is on the structural design. The ambition is to produce a preliminary design that can be carried on to a final design without any large changes.

bibo:shortTitle: Lady 33 - IMS/IRC design.
bibo:abstract: This project consists in designing a racer/cruiser sailing yacht able to be rated in IMS and IRC handicap.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 41 feet traditional Gaff Rig schooner for oceanic cruising.
bibo:abstract:
The personal interest of the author for traditional yachts naturally led to develop the preliminary design of gaff rigged schooner. Wood came to the force as building
material in this kind of construction, but it has been included in the modern building technique of the cold moulded construction. The specifications of the boat as well as the materials and building technique classify this boat as a one-off construction, and then special standards of comfort had to be applied in the general arrangements and all along the vessel.
This report represents a preliminary design for a long range oceanic cruiser, where 4 to 6 peoples can be accommodated. The structure has been developed using the
American Bureau of Shipping rules and the Maritime and Coastguard Agency regulations have been followed for the construction details and stability.
This project appears as an original one according to the majority of modern cruising yachts encountered in every marina, it represents a certain idea of the cruising as well as particular feeling for the traditional things. Problems have been encountered during the project as technical informations about this kind of yachts was hard to find, the majority of the past architects using empirical data as well as rules of thumbs but no established
equations or formula!

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a multi purpose ferry.
bibo:abstract:
This study sets out to source a suitable hull form and establish the necessary design considerations to produce a multi purpose commercial vessel.
The multi purpose ferry design is aimed to provide a vessel that has the ability to carry passengers and/or cargo to and from Bardsey Island situated on the North Wales coastline.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of an ORC GP33 racing yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of the dissertation is to outline the preliminary design of an ORC GP33 class racing yacht.
The author is particularly experienced in one-design keelboat and fleet racing. This design aims to produce a sensible, easily built and competitive GP33 class racing
yacht.
The preliminary design was driven almost exclusively by the initial weight estimate, influencing all aspects of the design spiral. Wind analysis was carried out on the
proposed racing region and the yacht was refined for sailing in these conditions.
Whilst stability and reducing wetted surface area were key factors in optimising the boat during the iterations of the design process, from its inception the boat was to be light weight and aimed at being as fast as possible for the assumed wind conditions.
Velocity prediction was made extensive use of, for this project, to ascertain the optimal hull parameters, as well as comparing performance to an already built and proven GP33.
This project proposes an easily built, fast and relatively cheap entry in to Grand Prix
fleet racing.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 46ft IRC competitive racing yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of the dissertation is to outline the preliminary design of a 46ft (14m) racing yacht, with a view to competitively racing under RORC's IRC rating system.
The jS46 is an attempt to answer the design brief of a competitive racing yacht to compete in a range of conditions and races. The author is particularly experienced in this field of yacht racing. The proposal was to produce a solution, which is both a sensible easily built design, fit for purpose, whilst meeting both the performance and rating expectations, as well as being an aesthetically pleasing boat, the focus on performing under the rating rule being the most recurring focus during the design process.

This dissertation has relied heavily on the use of performance prediction, with the aid of trial IRC time correction numbers, against a trial boat that is both similar in concept and a proven performer whilst racing in IRC regattas and events.
The preliminary design was driven heavily by the initial weight estimate, influencing all aspects of the design spiral, whilst stability was a key factor in optimising the
boat during the later iterations of the design process, from its inception the boat was to be light weight and aimed at being faster than its IRC TCC, rather than an exercise in slowing the boat less than its rating drops.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a 60’ high efficient motor yacht.
bibo:abstract: The aim of the project is to create a 60’ high efficient motor yacht focusing on the study of its dynamic behaviour to ascertain a correct power prediction. Design feature such as hydrofoils, mounted between two hulls of the catamaran permit to predict, in terms of a design speed, a low power required to displacement ratio. Beside this achieved efficiency, this craft has been designed to comply with the Maritime & Coastguard Agency regulation rules in order to be used as a chartered day boat in the Mediterranean Sea.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 50 -70 foot Slender Hull motorboat.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of the project is to produce a preliminary design of a medium speed slender hull motor boat with a length between 50 – 70 feet. The boat will be fuel efficient and
capable of long passage making at a medium speed. The motorboat will have to be designed to recreational craft directive standards (RCD).
The choice of a slender body hull form was chosen to provide a suitable platform to produce an efficiently powered motorboat that is more economical than the current
trend of motorboats. The current trend is to produce high volume motorboats with large interiors and reasonably heavy displacement, these requirements do not lend itself to an
efficient hull form. Instead huge engines are required to push the boat to a top speed required by the owner, even though when cruising, the boat will not often operate at
the top speed because of the cost and limited range. The slender hull motorboat will not be capable of reaching the speeds capable by a planing motorboat but will have a
sprint speed capability. The cruising speed of the slender hull is above that of a standard displacement cruising boat which for the size range is below 10kts. The idea is
that the slender hull form motorboat can cruise economically at a speed of 0.45-0.5 Froude No (Fn) with a range making it possible to larger distances. The sprint speed is there for short journeys where fuel efficiency is not so important and increases the possibility of travelling to further locations in a short time, which is one of the advantages of a planing motorboat.
The motorboat will be designed to be comfy, a stable for offshore cruising, it will have berths to accommodate up to 6 people with separate showers and head for each cabin.
With a slender body hull form the volume per length is less this makes the accommodation a factor in the decision of the overall length of the vessel. The project looks at layout options to optimise the interior space and flow, making it user friendly and supplying adequate room.
With a slender hull, stability is one of the major issues that have been looked into, RCD
have criteria that needs to be met, the project looks at the effect of varying the waterline beam and the vertical centre of gravity and where the limits in the hull form
are with minimum beam and VCG being found.
With part of the brief being an efficient hull form, resistance and propulsion were another important aspect of the project. Analysis of varying hull forms was undertaken
using Wolfson Powering Program to find the key factors affecting the resistance of the vessel.
The Final Vessel came to a length of 20.2m overall and beam of 4.75m, it has a cruise speed of 13 knots and a range of 1017nm. It meets the criteria for the both range and
speed and also supplies accommodation for 6 people. The vessel also passed RCD stability requirements for Category A.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a charter and research yacht for the Polar regions with reference to impact resistance.
bibo:abstract:
This report presents the preliminary design of a 25m explorer sailing yacht intended for charter and research in the Polar Regions. The high latitudes pose special demands on a vessel in all aspects of design due to their harsh climate and remoteness. It has been tried to fulfill these requirements as best as possible resulting in a seaworthy yacht that possesses the necessary strength to cope with the
cold and rough seas and provides sufficient shelter for the crew.
The vessel is intended for operation in light ice conditions only. However, as despite modern navigation equipment collisions with icebergs still occur, it has been tried to ascertain the yacht’s ability to withstand contact with sea ice as well as the survivability of a collision with a small iceberg. The energy absorbed by the structure
and thus the damage caused by an impact has been calculated the using the methods developed by V.U. Minorsky (1959) and Pedersen et al. (1993 cited in Lützen, 2001, p.59).
The present paper shows the work done in the course of the final year project of the BEng (Hons) Yacht & Powercraft Design. It has been the author’s aim to apply and expand the engineering knowledge gained during the past three years of this degree to develop a suitable preliminary design, including hull shape, structural calculations
and general and systems arrangements.

bibo:abstract: This project is an overview about the design of a 40-feet sailing yacht in FRP that would be used in the Swedish archipelago.
