bibo:shortTitle: Stabilised interlocking rammed earth blocks: alternatives to cement stabilisation
bibo:abstract: Southampton Solent University with the Good Earth Trust promotes projects in Africa that utilise interlocking rammed earth blocks. The earth used is typically a sandy clay or lateritic soil (red murram), stabilised with between 5-7% cement to improve the strength and durability of the blocks.  Only a small quantity of water is necessary to compact the material in the ram and to allow for the hydration of the cement.  The interlocks between the blocks reduce the need for 10mm mortar joints.  Testing with different soils, surface treatments, lime and cement stabilisers were conducted at Southampton Solent University, UK (Browne, 2005).  Ongoing tests at Makerere University in Uganda are researching the use of enzymes and polymers in providing innovative low carbon alternatives to cement. This paper introduces the use of this technology and assesses the different stabilising options to produce low carbon earth blocks.

bibo:shortTitle: A preliminary design for a small swath petrol craft.
bibo:abstract:
The proven ability of SWATH ships to maintain good speed in rough seas while retaining remarkable seakeeping qualities compared to conventional ships of equal displacement makes the generic SWATH hullform a realistic choice for future patrol craft. This project is concerned with the preliminary design and development of a small SWATH patrol vessel with search & rescue capabilities.
The process of derivation of a suitable hullform and basic hydrostatic checks are described. Structural design and structural weight estimates are performed. Resistance predictions using basis vessel tank testing and powering estimates are included. Particular emphasis is placed on aesthetic & ergonomic development using 3D computer modelling.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a fast carriage / slipway launch lifeboat for the RNLI
bibo:abstract: This dissertation is a preliminary design of a fast carriage/slipway launch lifeboat. The vessel is to be designed for the RNLI to replace the present Mersey class lifeboat. The design must satisfy the stringent requirements expected by the RNLI of all its modern lifeboats. In order to assess the requirements of the project, research into all aspects of design have been carried out. These include the feasibility and stability in particular. The first few turns of the design spiral are worked through, developing and refining the design with the aim to producing a preliminary design, which can be taken and developed further. Throughout the dissertation particular areas which will require further investigation are considered.

bibo:shortTitle: Investigation of the strategies planned by the Greek shipping companies regarding the implementation of the MARPOL annex VI
Bouillarta - Orma 60 trimaran with special study on seakeeping
bibo:abstract: The aim of this project is to design a 60 ft racing trimaran capable of racing in the ORMA-60 championship. To produce a competitive boat, it is first important to be aware of all the latest technologies used in the design. Considered as the Formula ones of the sea, the development of such vessels is fast moving. It is therefore compulsory to integrate all the latest innovation in the design. Those evolutions are made in different fields but yet; they are complementary in the final design. For example, using the latest material for the construction allows weight saving. Nevertheless, to conserve the same ability to carry sail, the distance between the hulls has to be increased.

bibo:shortTitle: A 6.5m boat for the Mini-Transat.
bibo:abstract:
The main aims of this dissertation are done first to validate some naval architecture and marine engineering concepts learned during the B.eng Yacht and Powercraft design three years course, and secondly to investigate more deeply some of these on a concrete example.
The choice to design a 6m50 boat responding to the minitransat rules, fitted with a canting keel and a set of efficient appendages has been seen by the author as a good challenge and an interesting task to investigate.
The main aim was then to arrive with a final product that would be able to cross the Atlantic safely and to be in the competition in terms of performance with the actual existing leader boats. It has to be said here that results in races depends as much on the level of the man on board, the tactic and the preparation as the pure boat naval architecture performances.

bibo:shortTitle: New and Recent Publications by Brandon Taylor
bibo:abstract: A list of new and recent publications by Professor Brandon Taylor, Senior Research Fellow, Southampton Solent University (last updated February 2010)

bibo:shortTitle: Hybrid lobsterboat
bibo:abstract:
The object of this project is to design a polyvalent fishing boat, capable to fish with different traps technique. 
The boat will be used in the Channel Sea, especially around the Minquier Island.

bibo:shortTitle: A fast offshore cruiser
bibo:abstract: This is the report on the design of ‘A Fast Offshore Cruiser’ which is to be normally sailed by a crew of two. The brief is for a fast but safe and comfortable, easily sailed good-looking yacht. This report covers the preliminary / conceptual work, hull and deck design, structures to ABS ’97 yacht rules, foil and rig design, general arrangement, stability and flooding and VPP. The content of the report shows the process taken by the designer to achieve the design shown that, the author believes, satisfies the requirements of the brief with ease.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a 10m match racer.
bibo:abstract: Match Racing in Europe is a growing form of sailing being promoted by several sailing federations, associations and yacht clubs.  There are different competitions such as World championship, European championship, etc… down to regional student trophy. That is to say that the discipline is nowadays very widespread.  However, there is not any European design for this kind of sailing practice and very few world-wide.  The objective of this dissertation is to design a 10 meters sailing yacht for this purpose.

bibo:shortTitle: A 12 metre high performance cruising trimaran
bibo:abstract:
In the history of sailing, multihulls have a great role to play, as they have been on the water for a lot longer than we can imagine. In fact, multihulls have existed ever since man discovered he could prevent his log boat from tipping over by lashing several together to form a raft, which was not only stable but could also carry a larger load.  These rafts, rigged with sails, are also believed to have travelled downwind thousands of miles across the Pacific Ocean by the first Peruvian settlers to the South Sea Islands. A constant evolution has occurred ever since from the Malanesians log-supported rafts to the Pacific Proa and today’s designs.
Unfortunately, multihulls have become not so popular over the years as people got afraid of them because of their tendency of staying upside down when the unlikely situation of capsizing occurs. Also, in the racing world, disasters implying loss of lives have not contributed in making multihulls attractive. But a lot of efforts have been made from designers to make multihulls both safe and seaworthy and an evolution in people’s mind is already visible.
Here, the idea was to design a cruising trimaran of a reasonable size to allow long distance cruising for people keen on speed and great sensations. The author always considered the performance as a priority in this design even though the boat had to be kept simple and suitable for family cruising. Many aspects of the design were studied and are fully described in their respective chapter together with possible improvements.

bibo:shortTitle: 24m fast cruising catamaran power-sailer
bibo:abstract: The aim of this design dissertation is to investigate the feasibility of a fast cruising motor-sailer between 20 to 25 metre which has good sailing performance and achieves 25 knots under power. The feasibility study leads to a catamaran as the most suitable vessel for this application. The preliminary design is developed and critical areas such as hull shape, propulsion and weight are investigated to a level that a judgement on the feasibility can be made. Since both performance under power and sail is critical to the feasibility of the vessel the performance is predicted by tanks tests and a VPP analysis. The investigation shows that such a vessel is feasible but requires engineering challenges to be solved.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a charter sports fisherman
bibo:abstract: As the most participated British sport, fishing has a huge popularity that continues to increase. In recent years there has been a significant growth in sea fishing with local clubs, tourist parties and private groups. A similar trend has also occurred throughout Ireland, particularly with the recent developments in Anglo-Irish politics. This has made way for the potential for more vessels in the tourist growth regions. A prime example is the Dingle Bay area of west Ireland that has a huge American and German clientele. This dissertation is the preliminary design for a vessel to fulfil this valuable market.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a tug for the Mayotte Island.
bibo:abstract:
The topic of this dissertation as been selected as a response to a real project : the tug company ‘SOMARSAL’ based on the MAYOTTE island has decided to acquire a new tug.
This dissertation has been executed as if a preliminary design was sent from a design office to the ship owner. The ship owner requirements were :
The ship might be classified with the ‘Bureau Veritas’. The tug should have to operate mainly at the Mayotte island merchant ship yard so it may receive an ability of navigation from the French customers ‘Affaires Maritimes’ as a 2nd category ship.
The tug should have a good maneuverability, a lower depth, to be robust and with a simple maintenance.
The tug produced might have a minimal traction force of 40 Tonnes.
The tug might be fitted with a fire fighting equipment of type ‘FIFI ONE’. The engine power should be enough to drive at the same time : one 600 m^3/h water pump, the auto-protection and still have enough power to prevent the water cannon reaction and to allow lateral displacement ; in fire fighting situation, it is important to keep enough power to go away backward quickly from the fire.
The machinery might be choose in function of these criterion but also keeping in mind to have a simplified maintenance and management of the spare parts, as Mayotte is situated far from any industrial country. This tug might also be designed to drive offshore rescue or towing operations with adapted fittings and an autonomy in fuel-oil and fresh water enough for 21 days on sea.
The tug might be used for pollution fighting operation, so a clear rear deck might
be required to receive anti-pollution package and any other tools for the operation. The rear deck might also be strong and large enough to receive two 20 feet containers.

bibo:shortTitle: Judicial debate behind closed doors? – Comparing how English judges and Danish judges influence each other when sentencing theft in the lower Courts
bibo:abstract: Presentation on research being undertaken as part of PhD research

bibo:shortTitle: A performance sailing yacht for corporate charter.
bibo:abstract: This report documents the initial design of a performance sailing yacht for corporate charter. Within the period of the investigation the implications of various aspects of design were looked at, these include safety requirements, ergonomics, aesthetics, sail choice, in particular the practicalities of having inexperienced sailors on board and what can be done to enhance there participation in sailing the boat. There is also a study looking in to the draught restriction imposed on the design by the requirement to use a wide range of anchorages within the operational area of the West Coast of Scotland. The final design includes a lifting keel with a close look at the lifting and locking mechanisms.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a Bermuda ferry.
bibo:abstract: The following dissertation considers the design problem of replacing a ferry for an existing service in Bermuda. There are new speed and passenger requirements for the updated service as well as constraints over wash height. A design proposal is examined for suitability and feasibility.  The study looks at the mechanisms of wash generation and examines current methods for measuring and comparing wash between different vessels in addition to the effects of shallow water on high-speed catamaran operation.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into the design of a Six Meter.
bibo:abstract:
At the turn of the century some of the larger sailing clubs in Europe were using sail-area / length based rules.  These had several forms such as the Club de France Rule and the Y.R.A. Rule in Britain.  Because these rules varied from club to club as well as from country to country, it was difficult to create fair competition.  Although the Club de France Rule was used in the first Olympic regatta it was not considered adequate. 
In 1906 an effort was made to consolidate the various Rules and it was decided that the new Rule should produce seaworthy and desirable yachts with scantling design to conform to standards set down by the Lloyd’s Register. This was the beginning of the International Meter Rule, and the birth of the Six-, Eight- and Twelve-Meter Classes. (4)
The most popular of the Meter Classes is the Six having been an Olympic Class from 1908 until 1952. However since 1950’s the class has been in decline although it still has large fleet racing on the Mediterranean and the lakes of Europe.
The Meter Classes were the major development classes of the early part of the twentieth century with the first Genoa headsail appearing on a Six-Meter yacht racing at a regatta in Genoa. Because of their draft-limiting rule, most of the wing keel developments since Australia II (A Twelve Meter) have been in the Six-Meter class. Unlike other development classes the development has not come at the expense of the seaworthiness of the yachts and this is truly a credit to the architects of the Rule.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a safer open 60.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this dissertation is not to provide “magic” devices capable to re-right any capsized Open 60, nor to define definitive limits in stability to achieve for a 100% safety. This is simply not possible. The objective of this dissertation is to estimate, for a set of boats having different widths, the range of stability they miss in order for them to revert to an upright condition in a given sea state. The justification of some artificial devices proposed to decrease the inverted stability if they may be considered as reasonably reliable will also be investigated. The data obtained will be used to discuss the minimum stability criteria of the rule. Last but not least, this dissertation will provide a proposal preliminary design for a safer Open 60.

bibo:shortTitle: A 50' flybridge cruiser.
bibo:abstract:
The object of the following dissertation is the design of a 50’ cruising flybridge for the Mediterranean sea.

The choice of this subject has been dictated by the wish to better understand the work behind this kind of boat and in case try to innovate and improve it. 
Real industry has always been taken as a reference, and sometimes better solutions have been excluded because of economic or building reasons.

Main requirements of a flybridge of this size are in the first place comfort, elegant exterior and interior accommodation together with easy handling at reasonable speed.
The geographic operational area is the Mediterranean sea, so a range of 400 nautical miles has been considered sufficient for the boat, this distance can be easily achieved at a cruising speed of 23 knots in 17 hours. In case of bad weather, or for any other reason, the boat can achieve 33 knots of maximum speed. The use of the boat is not limited to the warmer months of the year, in fact its use can be extended because of the design and general arrangement that allows greater interior space at the lower deck of the boat.
The interior space has been designed to accommodate 8 persons, with three different cabins, and one for the crew, having always in mind to achieve a great versatility of spaces. 

Without neglecting the other aspects of the design spiral, the efforts of the author have been concentrated, as specified in the above requirements, on the conception of interior spaces and in the aesthetic aspects.
Furthermore  the structural analysis of the design has also been one of the main targets to achieve, this has been carried out by comparing scantlings and weight of the same kind of structure using Lloyd’s and ABS Registers.
Great care has also been taken into the presentation of the project, trying to explain as good as possible the main figures of the boat to an eventual customer.

The dissertation has been composed in three sections which comprise the main report, the appendices of spreadsheet and tables, and technical drawings.

bibo:shortTitle: Enforcing the rights and freedoms of disabled people: the role of transnational law (Part 1)
Adaptive intelligence - Essential aspects (This is an extended version of the article presented on the International Conference on Automatics and Informatics 2009.)
bibo:abstract: The article discusses essential aspects of Adaptive Intelligence. Experimental results on optimisation of global test functions by Free Search, Differential Evolution, and Particle Swarm Optimisation clarify how these methods can adapt to multi-modal landscape and space dominated by sub-optimal regions, without supervisors’ control. In addition Free Search separately is evaluated on hard constraint global optimisation problem with unknown solution. It illustrates Free Search abilities for adaptation to unknown space. The achieved results are compared and analysed.

bibo:shortTitle: Editorial
Legal comment:  Freemasonry.  Is Freemasonry lawful in England?  Can the Government or other public body or employer prevent or penalise membership of Freemasonry?
The preliminary design of a marine ambulance for the Channel Islands.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this design dissertation is to investigate the design of a marine ambulance vehicle for the Channel Islands. It must have a fast response time to get to casualties quickly but there must be ample seakeeping properties so as not to cause adverse discomfort to otherwise afflicted people. Critical areas analysed are the general arrangement, stability, seasickness and hull shape. These have been investigated to a level of preliminary design. Structural arrangement has also been investigated as well as the design of a propeller. The investigation has produced a preliminary design capable of fulfilling the design objectives.

bibo:shortTitle: A trailer-sailer for amateur boatbuilding.
bibo:abstract: Amateur boatbuilding has become an attractive hobby in the last fifty years on the yachting scene, and the design of a trailer-sailer for this purpose has been seen by the author as a topic challenging and demanding enough for his BEng (HONS) Yacht & Powercraft Design final year dissertation. This present dissertation tries to cover all the subjects taught during the degree through a complete design loop. The design process started at an early stage by defining what are the limitations and requirements of such a vessel, followed by parametric studies of similar yachts. It was followed by the hull design, general arrangement and structural calculations, which were completed via the help of the American Bureau of Shipping rules for Classification of Offshore Racing Yachts. After a detailed weight estimate, the stability of the design was obtained by a hydrostatics package, determining the ability for the yacht to carry sails. The author presents in conclusion his time log spent on this dissertation, plus an evaluation of the further work that will be necessary to finalise this project.

bibo:shortTitle: Borealis 42 - ultra light (offshore) cruising boat.
bibo:abstract:
The owner, an ex-professional sailor, wanted a sailing vessel that could:
-	accommodate his family of 5 in harbour.
-	cross an ocean safely.
-	be easily handled with a crew of skipper and 2 experienced others at sea.
-	have the ability to do 180 mile 24 hr runs in trade wind conditions.
-	be possible to build by himself with his family.
-	be affordable.

bibo:shortTitle: A preliminary design of the new fire fighting vessel for the Duisburg industrial inland harbour.
bibo:abstract:
The design proposal of a fire-fighting vessel for the Duisburg industrial inland harbour can be considered as an exceptional challenge since the unique harbour and its surrounding environment require a vessel which is only one of its kind.
The vessel will be the successor of the existing one, which has now been in service for over 30 years. The new vessel needs to be fitted out with up-to-date equipment in order to be competitive for at least 20 years without any major
refitting work to be done. Within the scope of this dissertation it is intended to produce a preliminary design of such a vessel with special emphasis on hull performance and structural design. Due to the elative complexity of this project, some areas within the complete design are only investigated briefly.

bibo:shortTitle:
Illustrations published in Southern Daily Echo:
Donations pour in for tribute to city fallen, p.7, 25/06/09
bibo:abstract: Drawings prepared to show the new design for the First World War Cenotaph in Southampton. The Cenotaph war memorial in Watt's Park/West Park was built in 1919 and designed by the architect Sir Edwin Lutyens. Many of the names engraved onto the memorial are now unreadable and the proposal is to build two low walls to re engrave the names on.

bibo:shortTitle: Illustrations commissioned by the Bargate Gallery for presentation to planning committee to develop the Bargate monument.
bibo:abstract:
The Bargate is a Grade I listed building and a scheduled monument. Constructed in Norman times as part of the fortified walled city, the Bargate was the main point of entry and exit to and from the north of the city. Having been closed to the public for many years, the room above the gate was opened in 2006 as an art gallery by the arts organisation A Space. 

Brief
To prepare watercolour visuals showing proposed alterations for presentation to Southampton City Council. Artworks are to be used as part of an initial planning application for approval to carry out improvements to the monument. Visuals comprised:
•	a street view perspective of the south elevation. 
•	a street view showing details of proposed retail outlet.
•	interior perspective of the proposed café and reception area.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 110' luxury sailing yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The 1930’s were a classic era in sailing, epitomised by large J-Class yachts with their amazing looks and performance.  The J-Class yachts were the first Superyachts.  They were large, fast and expensive and racing was of prime importance.
Recent developments in sail handling, the use of better materials and the ability to provide high levels of comfort and good sail performance have created a demand for large luxury yachts.  An attempt to recapture the classic era has led to the development of the modern classic, a combination of the classic style with modern standards in comfort and performance.

The aim of the project was to perform the preliminary design of a 110’ luxury sailing yacht.

The project is intended to cover the design processes to achieve a preliminary design.
•	The requirements of the yacht will be defined and prioritised. 
•	A parametric study will be carried out.
•	Parameters will be determined.  
•	A hull form will be produced. 
•	Structural details will be obtained.
•	A general arrangement will be laid out.
•	A weight estimated performed. 
•	Appendages will be designed.
•	 A rig and sail plan will be designed.  
•	A stability analysis will be carried out.  
•	The design will be evaluated for using Velocity Prediction Programs.

It must be noted that these are steps in the design process and many of the stages will be repeated a number of times as better and more information becomes available.

On completion of the project it is hoped that a viable proposal for a design, which fulfils requirements, can be presented to a client.  A number of iterations in the design process would have been completed.

bibo:shortTitle: A round the world 40' fast sailing cruiser.
bibo:abstract:
Aim of this project is to develop the Preliminary Design of a fast cruising yacht able of performing in all possible sea and weather conditions, maintaining safety and comfort.
A simple but innovative ocean going yacht that can offer a comfortable living to a full crew but that can also be handled by a crew of two. Hence the final purpose is hence to join various and essential aspects such as comfort, cheap
building cost, innovation, performance, seaworthiness, all “blended” inside the appealing look of this yacht named Linda.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a 9.5m racing yacht for the "Classe Figaro".
bibo:abstract:
The objective of this project is to design a 9.50m racing yacht from the requirements of the Figaro class in order to change the actual Beneteau Figaro. After ten years of racing, the Figaro class has decided to draw up requirements to design the future one-design, which will be produced in 2003.  The requirements have done by the authority of the Figaro Class and 80 “Figaristes”  (racers).

Finot and Berret designed the actual Figaro in 1990.  Beneteau has built 120 boat of this type.  The boat is powerful and it can be used in single-handed or with crew.  This yacht is one of the most successful racing yachts in France.  The races are usually offshore and the most known are in single-handed “La Course du Figaro” and in doubles “La Transat AG2R”.  The Yacht is used also for crew events such as the week of “La Rochelle”, “Le Spi-Ouest-France” and many other races in order to have professional sailor.

The new one keep the spirit of the actual Figaro but it will be longer in length and could be benefit of the new technology specially in the building method and materials.  It will be inexpensive one-design.  This concept allows having less difficulty to buy a boat and to have many sailors. 

The drawings were done on Macsurf and Autocad.  The structural design was calculated from ABS requirements and many spreadsheets were used to calculate rig, mast, appendages and so on.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a formula 28 catamaran
bibo:abstract:
Having done a project of designing a motorboat in the 2nd year, the author’s interest of designing a sailing boat for his 3rd year project was reinforced. The choice was then between a multihull and a monohull. The advantage of the students of Southampton Institute is that they can use some modern tools like the towing tank, or the wind tunnel. The choice of dissertation was then turned to experimentations and testing.
Looking to the past dissertation, most of the designs have been done on monohull. Hence, a large quantity of information is available. The interest of doing some testing on multihulls was an evidence for the author.
In order to compare the results to existing boats, a choice has been done to use a class of boat that is regulated by rules. Consequently, the dissertation is about designing a formula 28 catamaran. This class is regulated by very precise rules. It is a racing boat that has to be habitable. 
After a quick calculation, it has been proved that the boat is too light, compared to the length and the beam, to fit in the towing tank. The formula 28 catamaran weights 750 kg for 8.53m long and 5.4m width around.
Today, the formula 28 boats are not used for cruising, despite the boats have a minimum of accommodations. The design was then orientated to use the catamaran for cruising as much as racing.

bibo:shortTitle: 13.5 cold moulded cruising yacht, analysis of the laminated hull shell.
bibo:abstract:
Although the preliminary design of a cruising yacht seems to lack the challenge of novelty, the subsequent evaluation of the wooden shell structure by first principle calculations proofed to be a valuable gain of knowledge in applied structural analysis. This is not only applying theory studied during the course but also the autodidactic approach to gain deeper knowledge in the mechanics of fibrous materials.
In the context of the following report this means that a preliminary design package for a cold moulded sailing yacht is proposed as well as an investigation in its laminated hull shell.
The present outcome of the project encourages to further investigations, regarding different angle ply layups and associated effects on stress and strains.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a harbour tug for the Solent region.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of the project was to produce a preliminary design of a harbour tug for the Solent. The opportunity to learn was one of the key aspects of the project. The content of the project is often beyond what would be expected from a preliminary design.
The project incorporates what has been learnt during the three years of study. The project has been a steep learning curve, a true case of application of theory, often beyond what had been experienced in the course.
The preliminary design, if taken further, is imagined, in the author’s opinion, to result in a very versatile harbour tug.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of an IRM 10.7m level rater.
bibo:abstract: Since two yachts first sailed on the same stretch of water, and due to the competitive nature of man, it was only a matter of time until someone came up with the idea of a handicap system to allow different types of vessel the opportunity to race against each other on a level playing field.  These handicap rules evolved from the original tonnage rules, through meter type rules, the IOR (International Offshore Rule) and IMS (International Measurement System), bringing us up to present day.  This report aims to produce an optimised design under the new IRM rating rule.  The chosen yacht is a level rater and as such will have a maximum rated length of 10.7m and time correction factor of 1.030.

bibo:shortTitle: The design of a SWATH for corporate entertainment.
bibo:abstract: The following project proposes a vessel for the Mediterranean which is suited to this propose, the Mediterranean was chosen as 70 percent of all the major events in Europe take place there and the European 49er Grand Prix Circuit is run from a small sea side resort about 80 km east of Marseille, called Bandol. It is noted however that 49er Grand Prix sailing alone would not generate the revenue to make this vessel viable, however, with proper management it could be made so if it is chartered for other events i.e. Tour de France a la Voile, Start and finish of ‘The Race’, Student match racing world champions, Mum 30 worlds and the Formula one Grand Prix in Monaco.

bibo:shortTitle: Open 40' for North Atlantic racing.
bibo:abstract: Open 40' for North Atlantic racing.

bibo:shortTitle: A Micro cup class yacht.
bibo:abstract: The original design brief for this project was to design a small racing boat fit for amateur building yet still allowing world class racing at a low cost. Usually, the solution to this search is to go for the mini-6.5 m. class, but lately, the budget needed to have good hopes of winning the race is not far from £150 000 (established designer and professional build quality). This was judged excessive as it makes it necessary to have a sponsor. The other solution is to go for a smaller boat: a Micro.

bibo:shortTitle: "Genesis" - The foil assisted monohull concept, an alternative for offshore racing.
bibo:abstract: This dissertation a attempt to bring together all the factors of velocity for an offshore sailing monohull without any limit but the logic, the first principles of physics, naval architecture, the handling and the safety concern. The main subjects involved are sailing equilibrium and various part of hydrodynamic. With the help of studied comparable boats, towing tank experiments and some will of originality, it produces a deeply revisited concept of racing monohull that is finally hybrid with multihulls on most of the major points.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design for a Versatile Coastguard Vessel (VCV).
bibo:abstract:
Where national boundaries allow, any country with a coastline has the right to enforce its maritime interest over a territorial zone up to 12 nm off shore and may patrol an Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of 200 Nm off shore.  Countries with successful economies achieve this through coastguard organisations backed up by naval resources and huge defence budgets.  However, some countries are restricted by their economies and are therefore constrained in the range of cover that they are able to provide.  This provides the market with a vessel, that at relatively low cost, can be used to police the countries EEZ whilst allowing the versatility to cover a range of further operational requirements that may be needed to defend national interests.  
To this end the proposed vessel is designed around the following key criteria:
•	A robust vessel giving low through life costs 
•	A need to be highly versatile in the roles it may perform
•	The ability to be modified from its primary role with the minimum of time and expense
This report identifies how the criteria is to be met through the use of a fixed set of vessel parameters including the hull form, powering and command and control systems with the versatility achieved through the introduction of changeable wet and dry mission modules.  To further maximise versatility these modules are to be sized to the internal capacity of haulage minicons and are able to be removed from their containers and plug directly into, and interact with, the existing vessel systems.  The objective of this design is to provide a good balance between the performances in the primary role, which the vessel will undertake through most of its life, and a range of secondary roles.

bibo:shortTitle: An Open 50' for Adriatic races.
bibo:abstract:
The boat has to be design for in and offshore races in the Adriatic Sea; the length is been chosen based on the local regulations and for a compromise between light and strong wind characteristics. 
A canting keel system will be developed to increase the stability in strong winds conditions keeping the displacement not very high. For the use of the canting keel system a front dagger board is necessary to increase the side force of the boat; to maximize the boat performances is been decide to use two asymmetric dagger boards, fore the mast, one in each side. The study of their Lift and Drag coefficient is been taking into account to optimize their performances; various NACA profile has been take in consideration.    
The boat is design as fully racing boat so all the criteria are focalized for its functionality, maneuvers and simplicity of the deck lay out; a large open cockpit is required for an easy crew disposition during maneuvers. A height of 1.85 m is required in the inside of the coach roof for an easier crew liability and to keep a good relationship between the length of the boat and its height. To make the boat faster in light-wind conditions, high SA/Δ and SA/WSA ratios have to be reach. The mast design will focus on the performances in light wind conditions with the forestay height on 9/10 of the mast length with the possibility to use a masthead asymmetrical spinnaker and a “code-zero”. Two runners and backstay for each sides and shrouds with few degrees angle of sweptback spreader will support the mast.
The hull will be built in E-Glass composite material; for all the appendages carbon laminates will be use as more sensible in term of performances. The boat will be built as “one off” design with a male mould.

bibo:shortTitle: 45' hard chine ocean-going cruiser.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of this project was the preliminary design of a fast around the world 45’ cruising yacht.
Round the world boats are generally seen as heavy steel or aluminium construction, low in performance, because it is not a priority, and are very large at the mid-ship to give large internal space.
Those kind of boats are adapted to be moored but generally, the weight and difficulty to move is not adapted to a day boat program.
This design is a different approach from the classic round the world boat as pleasure of speed is an integrated parameter.
She was conceived for a large range of customers who are looking for a personalised, fast and beautiful boat answering a large range of programs.
This project is named Waypoint

bibo:shortTitle: One off 29 - a custom cruiser-racer.
bibo:abstract: The subject of this dissertation is to design a 29’ Cruiser Racer with a particular study into shallow draft appendage efficiency. In order to treat the subject with a more realistic approach, the design follows fictitious requirements. The principal objective is to be involved as much as possible in a professional content, creating real interest and challenging situations.

bibo:shortTitle: Scuba diving support boat.
bibo:abstract:
Scuba diving in Europe is start to become increasingly popular and consequently the Diving Centre sees more divers each year. It’s often necessary to use a vessel to transport the divers to the principal diving site.

In general, the majority of the Diving Centres do not have a vessel designed and adapted for the diving. These vessels are pilot boats, fishing boats converted into Diving boats, which often are in poor condition and have few facilities. Therefore, the safety and the diving comfort leave much to be desired. These points were the main problem areas that Divers from the Diving Centre saw.
The necessity to contain the security and the comfort in a Diving boat is fundamental. Restricting the cost for the customer is an important point.

bibo:shortTitle: A Transat 6.50m boat with daggerboard comparison.
bibo:abstract: The Open class rules allow a lot of design improvements. The Minis are at the origin of many new ideas and concepts which were later used by some bigger boats. A lot of development has been done on the appendages and some more research can be done, it could be interesting to compare the lift and the drag produced  by an asymmetric daggerboards and those produce by a canard (symmetric daggerboard). This is the principal object of this dissertation. The investigation will be done using the towing tank. This is a preliminary design therefore some area have been more developed than some other.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a sea fisheries research / survey vessel.
bibo:abstract: The submission of a Proposal design to a tender document is a valuable exercise, commanding the pooling of the designers engineering knowledge and experience to produce a suitable proposal, within a potentially restricted time scale.  The following dissertation is a response to such a tender issued in October 2000; to a preliminary design stage, and as such has enabled the knowledge gained throughout the course to be applied in every aspect.  The principle objective of the dissertation was the ability to evaluate and accommodate the requirements of the organisation, and operations being inferred or indicated within the tender document; whilst endeavouring to introduce recent concepts to produce a competitive design, as is generally expected for tender proposals

bibo:shortTitle: Employer engagement academic staff professional and industry body involvement and added value to the student curriculum
Gaining academic value from extra-curricular work
IMS 35.
bibo:abstract: The aim of this design is to create a 35ft IMS racer optimised for upwind conditions at medium winds. The small size of the boat makes easier to go deeper into the structure study with ABS rules and make a more accurate weight estimation. This is really important to do the vpp anlysis under IMS rules and with the Wolfson Unit program.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a single-handed Open 60 with a 2-D keel.
bibo:abstract:
The precursors of racing alone around the world were Bernard Moetessier and Eric Tabarly; they contribute a lot to the expansion of offshore races, as public interest grew for those incredible races, media coverage developed, thus leading to an exponential growth of racing budget. The “OPEN class” is been constantly developed for the last twenty-five years, the regulations allow this technologic evolution and favoured innovative design, nowadays the materials and the advanced technology used to build an open-class allows them to sail very fast. The number of competitors increased and the standards of racing raised. The cost of an Open 60 campaign is constantly rising, it is about one million £ a year.
 The boat changed radically, getting wider to increase power while displacement was dropping and sail area enlarged to amazing extents, making them the fastest ocean racing monohull (achieving a velocity of 35 Kts in extremes conditions). The safety of those yachts is an important issue as they are sailing around the world in the worst sea condition. The stability requirements are strict and have to be approved by some organisations.

bibo:shortTitle: Formula 28' trimaran.
bibo:abstract:
To complete the Yacht and Powercraft Design course, a design project must be accomplished. The objective is to integrate and consolidate the academic work undertaken in all subject area.
The author of this report is very interested on the design of racing multihull. That is why he has chosen to make his study about a Formula 28’ trimaran.
In the history of sailing, multihulls have a great role to play, as they have been on the water for a lot longer than we can imagine. Today, they are developed to the point of having exceptional performances in front of the monohull.
As the Formula 28’ is a racing multihull class, so the design must strictly respect the rules to be able to take part to the Champion-Ship.
Most of the final design process areas are covered, always comparing with all kind of existing multihull to remember in which way the boat must be developed.

bibo:shortTitle: A 40ft trimaran for single and shorthanded trans-Atlantic racing.
bibo:abstract:
This design was initiated with two principal objectives, the first was to produce a multi-hull yacht capable of racing competitively in any of the number of shorthanded Trans-Atlantic races, and specifically with the Europe 1 STAR (originally the OSTAR) race in mind.  The second objective was to provide a smaller, less expensive alternative to the ever more costly open 60 trimarans,  for which the build cost has approximately doubled since 19971.  The reasoning behind this was that a less expensive class could be more attractive to sponsors as there would be less financial risk involved and secondly it would provide younger sailors with a stepping stone into the larger open 60’s.  Looking towards the open style mono-hulls it can be seen that there are moves towards this.  The open 60 mono-hulls are now commonly racing along side open 50’s and currently many designers have open 40 style yachts on their drawing boards.
At this stage while the size of yacht had been determined, the hull configuration was unknown, the two main types are of course the catamaran and trimaran although it was decided that a proa may provide an interesting alternative.  It was therefore necessary to examine the various qualities inherent in each configuration.

bibo:shortTitle: SEM44 - Preliminary design for a cruiser with lifting keel.
bibo:abstract:
The sailing vessel described in the following pages is an attempt to fulfil the desires of an experienced yachtsman/customer with precise ideas of the yacht he is looking for.
The ‘ideal’ yacht would be a fast cruiser with reduced draft for mooring or just approaching the shore. The design of the yacht has been carried out trying to provide a satisfactory balance between the requirements and the constraints that are involved in such a project

bibo:shortTitle: Hull form evolution for a high performance superyacht.
bibo:abstract:
The main aim of this project is the evaluation of a novel hull form in comparison with an ordinary hull form. Improving performance and comfort at the same time has been the philosophy that has driven the new concept.
A normal hull and a winged hull have been tested in the towing tank, the results have been input into the velocity prediction program and the two yachts have been raced at equal wind conditions. The analysis has shown a significant performance edge in favour of the new hull form, therefore the design has been finalised on the winged hull.

bibo:shortTitle: Mini transat 6.5m - design and structural comparison
bibo:abstract:
The principal object of this project was the design of a mini transat type boat and  the weight comparison between two similar structural arrangements made of different materials.
The choice of this subject was mainly due to the fact that the author already started to build its own mini transat, and wanted to evaluate the difference in weight between the two hulls  structural arrangements in order to answer the question: whether going for a high cost hull made of exotic materials or stay with a more conventional one.
In the preliminary stage of the work process, it became clear that the time needed to deeply investigate all aspect of the design wasn’t sufficient, and the early choices were made to neglect aspect such as ergonomic, bulb hydrodynamic etc in order to focus on main subjects such as design factors influencing the performances of a sailing vessel, the reliability of VPP tests on boats such as minis or similar ones and on the structural design.
Finally, the project gave the author the opportunity to put in practice some of the theory learnt during the degree, and to improve his understanding of the complexity of sailing boats, experience which reveals itself as widely useful in order to be well prepared to enter the industrial world.

Non-native marine invaders in British waters - causes and consequences
Freight forward agreements - shipping market players' perspective for their role in the risk management strategy
The design of a Thames A Class Rater.
bibo:abstract:
The aim of the project is to produce a complete design of a Thames A Class Rater. The concept of the design will be to generate a boat that will bring the class up to date with modern design and manufacturing techniques. But this must be done in a way not to disregard the long history of the class and also with out changing what people conceive a Thames A Class to be. 

Currently the class has between 7 – 10 boats, which are in full racing condition, the other boats are either in the process of restoration or lying dormant. The new design will incorporate a new hull shape, although this is in breach of the rules relating to the hull, which states “a new hull will only be considered to be an A Class Rater hull if it is an exact replica of an existing Rater, Taken from either an existing hull, or original lines, subject in both cases to a tolerance of one and half inches”. But after consultation with members of the rater association the consensus it that if a new hull shape can generate new inters in the class, without a direct influence on the standard of the racing it can only be a good thing.  With this in mind the new design will help to bring more people in to the association and help to make the A Class Rater as popular as is was when the first boats blessed the Thames with their classic lines.

bibo:shortTitle: Preliminary design of a 9.4m sailing boat for amateur boatbuilding.
bibo:abstract:
The subject of this project was chosen for many reasons, one of them is a personal attraction of the author for boats made of plywood. This relatively cheap material can be used with new processes and give birth to quite performing yachts. The second main reason for this choice is that it covers all the different aspects of the design process. 
During the study, the author encountered many difficulties. One of them was the structural calculations. Considering the particular aspect of the structural design, it was difficult to define the scantlings using the usual tools. A further study would have been interesting. 
One satisfaction of the author was that the final design of Biped, such is her name, fulfilled the design brief.
Finally, running this project gave an overview of the naval architect work, which requires good knowledge and skills in all aspects of the design process.

bibo:shortTitle: The preliminary design of a 19m cruiser/racer with trans-ocean capabilities.
bibo:abstract: It is has been noted that the general trend in modern cruiser/racer is for increasing performance equable to that of their, out and out racing colleagues. This has been achieved in part at the expense of cruising orientated luxuries, and lighter and inherently less robust construction or by using expensive composite materials, which is felt to be inappropriate for the vessels purpose. The aim was to produce a vessel that is a definite cruiser/racer with a distinct cruising slant.

bibo:shortTitle: Design of a 7.5m sportsboat.
bibo:abstract: "...designing a 7.5 meter daysailer for competitive racing under the Sportsboat Rule. Though the craft is small, it demanded consideration of the majority of disciplines covered through the course. Furthermore, for craft of this size, experience was already in place in terms of operation and construction, while it was an entirely new challenge to design to a rule."

bibo:shortTitle: The impact of the international ship and port facility security code on seafarer workloads
The application of environmental lessons learned from the plan to expand port of Southampton, United Kingdom to the future development of Apapa port in Lagos, Nigeria
Decision-making criteria for successful maritime outsourcing
Environmental auditing of the Esso Chad floating storage and offloading (FSO) vessel oil transfer activities on the marine and coastal environmental at Kribi - Cameroon
Evacuation issues in the next generation of passenger ships
When life gets in the way of learning
bibo:abstract:
Purpose: To examine the learning needs of Micro Enterprises (MEs) and to critically evaluate whether educators can deliver skills to meet their needs.
Design/methodology/approach: Both empirical quantitative and qualitative research paradigms will be engaged. Quantitative primary research will enable a more scientific controlled statistical measurement. Qualitative primary research using a naturalistic approach will be used to gain a deeper knowledge and understanding of the owner/manager needs to either support or the outcomes the quantitative research and/or offer up a different outcome and to understand whether certain variables are causally linked to others or not. Techniques such as qualitative interviews and quantitative questionnaires will be adopted.
Findings: Potential outcomes: that the external and internal influences on a Micro Enterprises do/do not impact on an individual’s learning decision, that Mes are not understood by educators or that they are understood but fail to deliver appropriate skill training due to other constraints and that educators need to make a paradigm shift in their methods of delivery. The findings will establish how these firms want to engage in learning new skills versus current delivery systems.
Value: Gaps in knowledge revolve around how educators could better interact with Micro Enterprises in a way that is meaningful and productive to them. Educators are not fulfilling their customers’ needs and these needs must be met if the UK economy is to be successful in a global economy. This paper will be of value to all educators who have contact with this sector

bibo:shortTitle: Management of container terminal operations: ABP Southampton
To investigate the role of ship vetting inspections as a risk management tool in improving safety at sea
The design of add-on sleeping accommodation for a rigid inflatable boat.
bibo:abstract:
There is a gap in today’s market in the Rigid Inflatable Boat industry for an add-on sleeping accommodation to bridge the gap between Open Rigid Inflatable Boats (RIBs) and Cabin RIBs.
As the leisure market in the RIB industry is expanding continuously people want to take their boats further a field, but can not afford the price increase to a Cabin RIB therefore an interim method is required.
Research data for popular sized RIBs, anthropometrics and ergonomics was collected and analysed to determine an ideal boat to base the accommodation on which fulfilled the design brief.
Add-on accommodation was designed to fit a Gemini Waverider 730. The accommodation consists of a semi permanent fibreglass, 3-section structure, a fold down canvass shelter and an inner tent with built in groundsheet to sleep in. The canvass folds down from the roof section on the structure when stationary and the inner tent is then clipped in place.
The design had to conform to towing regulations and the Recreational Craft Directives (RCD).
The effect the accommodation has on the RIB was evaluated. As the accommodation was estimated to weigh 80kg, the trim and performance of the RIB would not be affected. The maximum stress on the structure was calculated to be 2.43MPa and the lifting force 1236N.

bibo:shortTitle: What regulations need to be fulfilled for 'Jenny May' to be MCA compliant.
bibo:abstract:
The reason why this project was undertaken is that most reputable charter agencies require the boats that are listed with them to be compliant to a safety standard, the most common being the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA). 

‘Jenny May’ was purchased in the view to being one of those boats. This project therefore outlines the factors that need to be altered on the boat for it to be compliant in accordance to the MCA. This project also outlines what is involved in creating a successful charter business. This includes, marketing tactics, product placement in the market and forms of advertising. 

The boat was examined last year in accordance with the MCA ‘The safety of small commercial sailing vessels – a code of practice’ codebook. From this it was possible to establish what needs to be altered on the boat before it can receive its compliance. The marketing aspect of the project involved an in depth analysis of the charter market in order to find and exploit a niche.

From the research that I did on the boat I found that it would be feasible to upgrade ‘Jenny May’ to a MCA compliant vessel. Cost analysis charts were drawn up to give an idea of the expenditure involved in the process. After much research into the charter market I found a couple of areas that would allow me to create a competitive charter business. The first idea is to operate a flexible charter between low cost airports and at the same time penetrating the market to produce a quality charter holiday at a low cost. This therefore increases the demand and awareness of the company. The second idea is to charter in accordance to major sporting events around the world; at present there are mainly only super yachts that do this. We will therefore offer the option to tailor affordable charter packages to suit the clients’ requirements. 

This project therefore starts at the stage when the boat was purchased and covers all the aspects stated above to a financial forecast for the year 2005.

bibo:shortTitle: Feasibility study: converting a 1955 ex-Yugoslavian cargo-passenger ferry into a large commercial yacht.
bibo:abstract:
The large yacht market and, in particular, the large commercial yacht market is expanding at a greater rate than at any previous occasion – both in physical size of the vessels and the numbers that are available.

The pressure upon designers to be innovative is considerable at a time when many designs appear to be similar.  While there is plenty of evidence pointing to the conversion of merchant vessels from one use to another, this has been less obvious in the large yacht market.  Recently, the large yacht or “megayacht” industry has seen the completion of several retrospectively styled new builds as the desire for owners to express their individualism becomes paramount.  There are an increasing number of conversions of commercial vessels offering not only style, but space and a reassurance of quality build. These observations are discussed, focussing on the “Prince Albert” – a 1954 Yugoslavian cargo/ferry.

The vessel is subjected to survey, measurement and stability assessments. The regulatory bodies with rules pertaining to the “Prince Albert” are identified. The difficulties that may be encountered with compliance are discussed and solutions to the problems offered. As part of this process, a comparison of different materials is made, with particular emphasis being made of the substitution of steel for lightweight composites.

The problems associated with fire, fire exits and emergency escape routes are highlighted. The difficulties of acting in accordance with the internationally recognised Safety Of Life At Sea A60 fire test standards is also discussed with reference to both steel and composite materials.  Finally, an impression of the vessel with its modifications and an indication of the project management of such a conversion are presented.

The project finds that there is considerable work, which may not be immediately apparent, that needs to be undertaken to ensure success. The vessel appeared to show a flaw in its stability requirements that could mean failure to comply with classification authorities.  As the vessel has had considerable extra steel work added throughout its lifetime it is believed that this has contributed to this change. 

The vessel represents the style that is sought after in the large yacht market and would therefore make the conversion an attractive proposition. The conversion could be successful providing meticulous planning and budgetary control are exercised.

bibo:shortTitle: The importance of after-sales and warranty procedures for yacht manufacturers.
bibo:abstract:
The customer is the most important factor in any business, in todays market the level of after-sales service that the customer gets can often be a major influence in their satisfaction and therefore their willingness to make further purchases of the same brand. This is also true of the yacht manufacturing industry.

There are many items within the law of both Europe and the US that all yacht manufacturers should take into consideration. And with the recent introduction of the European Directive 1999/44/EC on certain aspects of the sale of consumer goods and guarantees there is know a more common way of dealing with this throughout Europe.  The laws that are applicable to the markets that the yacht manufacturers are selling need to be understood by all those that they affect, from both the manufacturers and dealers. 

The cost of setting up and carrying out high levels of customer care for motor yacht owners can be large including flying engineers across the world at a moments notice in order to solve problems with the yachts. This all costs money and must be accounted for in the cost of a yacht. Efficient quality control procedures can help to reduce the need for such travel to rectify problems as well as improving the overall quality of the yachts therefore raising the satisfaction levels of the customers.

The gauging of how customers feel about the product and the service that they receive is vitally important as without this it is not easy to improve the systems and product in terms of what the customer actually requires and wants.   

Above all the customer must be kept satisfied and it is the after-sales department within a yacht manufacturer that must do this in order to keep customers and help attract new ones.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into existing survival equipment / systems and the possibility of applying current technology to a new design.
bibo:abstract:
The project was undertaken as it was considered that, with an ever increasing number of people taking to the water in yachts, current survival equipment was not up to the task of offering maximum safety to the crews and vessels when compared to related technological advances in other industries.

To assess if there is a need for a new product, the project investigates a number of key areas. Initially the history of accidents at sea, specifically looking into the 1979 Fastnet and 1998 Sydney-Hobart races, previous accounts from sailors who have lost vessels and been stranded at sea and accident statistics. 

It then investigates what is currently on offer in the way of survival equipment in the marine industry and considers these against safety equipment in comparable industries.

After concluding that current systems, especially liferafts, have a large number of publicised shortcomings, a new design/ concept was conceived. The design utilises current liferaft technology and using a design employed in the aeronautical industry as its basis, incorporates an inflatable collar into the hull of the vessel. This design addresses all of the identified drawbacks and provides great improvements to vessel stability, crew safety and recovery.

To test the design all the data was entered into stability calculations. The results from this proved better than expected.

A 1/8th scale model was created using a Whitbread 60 hull. This model was subjected to an inclining experiment, the results of which were compared to the theoretical results for the same model to test the accuracy of the calculations. The results from both methods were very close. This proved that the theoretical method can be used to accurately predict increases in stability. In both cases the experiment was deemed a complete success.

The latter section of the report suggests ways in which the design can be incorporated into the hull to offer maximum results, whilst requiring as little effort from the crew as possible. It then investigates how to further develop the project and lists potential issues associated with a development program. 

These are overcome by the recommendation of introducing the design to a company who already has experience at producing marine safety systems. It also gives recommendations to the marine industry as to how best to improve the regulations for marine safety equipment so that a universal standard can be rapidly adopted.

A study of the market valuation of antique Chinese ceramics
bibo:abstract:
This research describes an attempt to postulate a grounded theoretical understanding of the valuation of objects described as art and antiques.

The approach adopted is fundamentally inductive and interdisciplinary.  It begins with a discriminating synthesis of the relevant literature from the disciplines of Art History, Sociology, Anthropology, Economics and Psychology.  Financial value is strongly correlated with aesthetic value, which is created partially through the process of exchange itself, but largely through the ascribing of 'meaning' to objects through social and historical mechanisms.  These mechanisms are examined using consumer behaviour paradigms.  The economic notion of 'artistic capital stock' is assessed for its wider applicability.

The study focuses on the creation of perceptions of cultural and financial worth, and valuation of antique Chinese ceramics, which through their inter-cultural complexity, are seen as illuminating a breadth of generalisable phenomena.  The creation of perceptions is viewed on both the level of encircling cultural predispositions, and on a level of more specific interactions between the consumer and what are viewed as marketing inputs.

The methodology adopted is one of cross-reference between qualitatively described observations derived from particiopation in the market, and quantitative behavioural analysis of a database compiled from the auction sales of Sotheby's and Christie's over a five year period.

The results indicate that consumers of 'art' are behaviourally similar to generic consumers of any goods.  Further they are risk-reducing seekers of autonomy through affiliation, which appears to compete in the fulfilment of their higher order psychological needs.  Culturally established mechanisms for the ascription of 'meaning' to 'art' objects are shown to correlate functionality with the creation of brand perceptions through the marketing of fast moving consumer goods.

The specific inputs which contribute to the perception of value, are identified and modelled.  Recommendations are made regarding a fuller examination of the 'valuation' process and the appropirateness of further examinations of the 'art market' by consumer behaviourists.

bibo:shortTitle: Cross-cultural management: is the local culture hinder or benefit to foreign banks operating in Slovakia?
Are angels priceless?
Learning styles and preferences of entrepreneurs
bibo:abstract: A lot is known about Micro Enterprises yet they continue to be an enigma worthy of further research. They are confronted with many challenges and in the light of these this workshop will start by briefly reviewing previous research in the area of skill acquisition. It will also introduce participants to a conceptual model which has been developed to underpin future research. The aim of the current research is to understand how learners might want to engage with educators to provide a more customer led delivery.

bibo:shortTitle: How do micro enterprises want to learn?
bibo:abstract: Objectives To examine the learning needs of Micro Enterprises and to critically evaluate whether educators can deliver marketing skills to Micro Enterprises to meet their needs. Prior Work Writers suggest that the marketing behaviour of small firms appears to be related to the motivation, belief, attitude and the objectives of the owner-manager and that when small businesses are formed, they are often based on a particular skill of the founder and that there are a number of barriers to learning. Academic research appears unable to resolve a number of questions about small businesses and their use of marketing and that further research is needed. Approach Micro Enterprises are relatively easier to identify and make contact with relevant individuals compared with larger organisations. The geographic area of Hampshire, United Kingdom, has been chosen because of its accessibility, segmentation will be by type, e.g. Sole traders, Partnerships and Limited Companies. Both empirical quantitative and qualitative research paradigms will be engaged and the results compared with studies undertaken in 2005 by Simpson, Padmore and Taylor. Method(s) A qualitative naturalistic approach is being used to explore the views, behaviour and experiences within Micro Enterprises compared to the quantitative data will give a more general and scientific overview. Techniques like qualitative interviews and quantitative questionnaires will be adopted as they are considered to be more appropriate in the field of social science research and in particular for this study. Results Potential outcomes: that the external and internal influences on a Micro Enterprises do/do not impact on an individuals learning decision, that Micro Enterprises do/do not really know what marketing is and do/do not engage in learning, that firms are not well understood by educators or that they are understood but fail to deliver appropriate skill training due to other constraints and that educators need to make a paradigm shift in their methods of delivery to Micro Enterprises. Implications The findings will establish how Micro Enterprises acquire and learn the skills to market their business and evaluate the needs and wants of Micro Enterprises and how they want to engage in learning new skills versus current delivery systems which are not customer led. Finally, after a critical analysis of whether educators can deliver marketing skills to Micro Enterprises to meet the needs and wants of this sector more effectively a new model will be developed to reflect the research results. Value The core value of this paper is to put forward a new model for discussion of how these firms could have marketing skills delivered to them in a way which matches their needs and wants. The research will then lead us into a deeper understanding of Micro Enterprises and the development of alternative ways of delivering marketing skills to them. Approaches to training will have to change if educators want to engage with this sector.

bibo:shortTitle: Clubs, Pubs, Sleep or Study: How can we better engage with learners’?
bibo:abstract:
This paper examines the learning needs of students and businesses and asks the question “Can educators deliver skills to meet the needs of an evolving business sector?”  

As recently as 2009 at the International Entrepreneurship Educators Conference the feedback from a workshop run by the author, participants indicated that the kind of activities they would want to engage in to acquire new skills (Wilman et al., 2009) So, should we be more focused on the learners needs versus what we want to teach?

Research suggests that a community bases approach to learning is successful because it focuses on the needs of the learner, and does not focus on evaluating learners (Redmond et al., 2008). Supporting this theory is a research study by the Learning and Skills Development Agency, which showed that employers and employees learn best from their everyday experiences, and place great value on informal learning rather than on taught courses or structured training programmes, (Anon, 2004). 

Project – based courses are favoured for the development of skills (Mc Mullan et al., 1991), which has been used with some success at the University of Alberta with some success (Preshing, 1991). Increasingly, educators are using experiential learning (Smart et al., 1999) which ties in with what employers want. Given the choice of a club, a pub, sleep or study, how can we better engage with students better?

bibo:shortTitle: No-one understands my business!
An investigation into the significance of the effect of safety equipment on boat speed.
bibo:abstract:
Does the weight of safety equipment have a significant effect on boat speed? 

Boats have been racing offshore for the best part of two centuries. This has been run as one designs as well as under all manor of handicap systems. Although handicap systems have come and gone, the range of yachts using them has changed little. Boats that race offshore are required to carry an inventory of safety equipment that, should they be needed, will help the crew get through any unexpected circumstances. However, this inventory adds up to a substantial weight. Not only is this weight not accounted for when a boat is weighed for her rating, but this weight varies considerably across a range of boat sizes. This is to be expected except that the weight varies approximately to crew numbers rather than displacement. This now sets up a problem as displacement varies cubically with length where as crew numbers vary almost linearly with length. 
	The aim of this investigation is to determine to what extent small boats are disadvantaged, if at all. This was carried out by comparing parametric data of geometrically similar boats of different sizes with the weight of safety equipment they would be expected to carry for each ORC special regulations category. A nominal crew number was be set for each boat.
Data was collected afloat by sailing a Dehler 34 around a triangular course with differing displacements. This was done six times, one for each ORC category and a lightship state. Data was collected by linking the boat’s instruments with a laptop computer. This data was then compared with the boat speed predictions made by a VPP and the change in TCF of the IRM formula. All three analytical techniques could then be compared with the additional weight the smaller boats carry over the larger boats. Weights and speed drops were all expressed as percentages for comparison. 

The six metre boat was found to be carrying five and a half times more safety equipment than the Maxi as a percentage of displacement. The data collected afloat suggested that a Dehler 34 was eight percent slower when loaded with ORC category 0 safety equipment. The VPP pointed to one percent slower and the IRM formula was only 0.1 percent slower when in the same loaded condition. 

	There is clearly a case that the range of weight that the safety equipment covers does have a significant effect on boat speed, but due to there being so many uncontrollable variables, a fuller investigation involving a greater range of boats and meteorological conditions needs to be carried out. This will enable more accurate figures to be put on these effects. The VPP cannot cope with some features of this investigation fully and so more time afloat is justified. More data would reinforce the case to issue a different TCF for each ORC category but of course crew numbers would then have to be enforced.

bibo:shortTitle: An investigation into the effect of reducing mast mass on the sailing performance of racing yachts built in the early 1900s.
bibo:abstract:
The author has always had great interest in large traditionally rigged classic sailing yachts, especially the way in which the rigs of such craft withstand the pounding that is received on the racetrack, and why more do not fail in heavy cruising conditions. 
With the obviously large loads exerted on all components for extended periods, it has intrigued the author how these vessels survive the rigours of time.
Also why one yacht may be obviously faster than another when they appear identical in every way.

This project sets out to quantify what:

•	governs the speed of similar vessels, by investigating the powerhouse of sailing yachts.
•	loads are distributed where in a traditional rigs, identifying where common problems occur, and what areas may be enhanced to improve both ease of handling and performance.
•	is required today of rig construction methods to comply with the classic yacht racing societies rules.  
  
Outlines of current issues are identified, which are at the forefront of this society. Addressing the rules on the inclusion of exotic materials in mast and rigging construction, and weighing up its validity.

The project evaluates one particular classic yachts current mast and rigging situation and by reasoned evaluation, theoretically suggests changes that could be made to enhance its performance, whilst not compromising the integrity of the yachts intact stability.

The gains and benefits of the enhancements are clearly documented. The project attempts to place even further understanding on what benefits can be achieved by reducing the mast mass of the case study yacht. This occurs by using conceptually alternative mast materials and techniques, although always retaining the true aesthetics of yesteryears masterpieces. However, always bearing in mind the governing concerns surrounding the certifying authorities such as ‘The Maritime and Coastguard Agency,’(MCA) ‘The Recreational Craft Directive’ (RCD) and ‘The Comité Internationale de la Méditerranée.’ (CIM)

Its findings predominantly flaw the argument that CIM has with the use of exotic materials in mast construction, as an unfair performance enhancer. 

The report demonstrates the use of such materials has minimal velocity gains in this application, due to the nominal overall effect that saving a certain percentage of just the mast mass has with vessels such as the yacht investigated.

bibo:shortTitle: A concept design for a smart material that detects microcracking in a composite laminate.
bibo:abstract:
In recent years a new field of materials technology has emerged, it is the research into smart materials.  This field involves research and development of so-called smart materials engaging piezoelectric materials, fibre optics and shape memory alloys.

Microcracking is an issue within the composite industry. The laminate has not failed, but it has started to breakdown well below the ultimate tensile strength.  Thus compromising the laminate.

The piezoelectric material can be utilised to make a very good sensor, and due to the number of commercially available piezoelectric materials this means that there is a material option for many applications.

The samples were made up of a typical hull laminate and piezoelectric film was attached to the laminate.  The film was bonded to the laminate using tape.  Microcracking was then induced in the laminate.  Preliminary results show that there is potential for the material, but a circuit needs to be developed to make use of the data and present the results.
